Phrases: ἄεθλα κεῖται or πρόκειται prizes are offered, Hdt. 8.26, 9.101; ἆθλα προφαίνειν, προτιθέναι offer prizes, X. Cyr. 2.1.23, Hier. 9.4; τιθέναι Pl. Lg. 834c; ἆθλα λαμβάνειν, φέρεσθαι to win prizes, Pl. R. 613c, Ion 530a, etc.; ἆθλον νίκης λαμβάνειν as the prize, Arist. Pol. 1296a30, cf. Th. 6.80; ἆ. ποιεῖσθαι τὰ κοινά Th. 3.82; τὰ ἆθλα ὑπὲρ ὧν ἐστιν ὁ πόλεμος D. 2.28; ἆθλα πολέμου Id. 4.5; τῆς ἀρετῆς Id. 20.107; βέλτιον τοῖς δούλοις ἆ. προκεῖσθαι τὴν ἐλευθερίαν Arist. Pol. 1330a33.

children.definition: gather together, collect, muster, ἀ. λαόν, etc., S. OT 144, etc.; τὸ βαρβαρικὸν καὶ τὸ Ἑλληνικόν X. An. 1.2.1; Τροίαν ἀ., gather the Trojans together, E. Hec. 1139; πνεῦμʼ ἄθροισον collect breath, Id. Ph. 851, cf. Arist. GA 738b7; περιπλοκὰς λόγων ἀθροίσας having strung together, E. Ph. 495: abs., hoard treasure, Arist. Pol. 1314b10:— Med., gather for oneself, collect round one, E. Heracl. 122, X. Cyr. 3.1.19:— Pass., to be gathered or crowded together, εὖτε πρὸς ἄεθλα δῆμος ἠθροΐζετο Archil. 104, cf. 60; ἐς τὴν ἀγορὴν ἀ. Hdt. 5.101; ἁθροισθέντες having rallied, Th. 1.50; τὸ δὲ. . ξύμπαν ἡθροίσθη δισχίλιοι but the whole amounted collectively to . ., Id. 5.6; ἐνταῦθα ἡθροίζοντο they mustered in force there, Id. 6.44, etc.; form a society, Pl. Prt. 322b; ἀθροισθέντες having formed a party, Arist. Pol. 1304b33: of things, περὶ πολλῶν ἁθροισθέντων taken in the aggregate, Pl. Tht. 157b.

definition: ἀθρόος, α, ον, ( ος, ον D. 19.228, Arist. PA 675b21, etc.), ἁθρόος in Hom. acc. to Aristarch. ap. Sch.Ven.Il. 14.38 and Att. (also some times ἅθρους, ουν, as Ar. Fr. 633, Hyp. Eux. 33, D. 27.35), poet.acc.pl. ἁθρόᾰς h.Merc. 106; dat. pl. ἁθροῖσιν Epigr.Gr. 1034 26 ( Callipolis):—but in later writers the spir. lenis prevailed: (ἀ- II, θρόος):—

children.definition: in crowds, heaps, or masses, crowded together, Hom. only in pl., as Il. 2.439, al.; ἁθρόοι . . ἅπαντες Od. 3.34, etc.: sg. first in Pi. P. 2.35; ἀθρόοι, of soldiers, in close order, Hdt. 6.112, X. An. 1.10.13, etc.; opp. ἀσύντακτοι, Id. Cyr. 8.1.46; in column, ib. 5.3.36; πολλαὶ κῶμαι ἁ. close together, Id. An. 7.3.9.

children.label: II
children.definition: together, in a body, ἁθρόα πάντʼ ἀπέτεισε he paid for all at once, Od. 1.43; ἁ. πόλις the citizens as a whole, opp. καθʼ ἕκαστον, Th. 2.60, cf. 1.141; ἁ. δύναμις Id. 2.39; ἁ. ἦν αὐτῷ τὸ στράτευμα was assembled, X. Cyr. 3.3.22; τὸ ἁ. their assembled force, ib. 4.2.20, cf. An. 5.2.1; ἁθρόῳ στόματι with one voice, E. Ba. 725; ἁ. δάκρυ one flood of tears, Id. HF 489; ἁ. λόγος a flood of words, Pl. R. 344d; ἁθρόους κρίνειν to condemn all by a single vote, Id. Ap. 32b; πολλοὺς ἁ. ὑμῶν D. 21.131; ἄθρους ὤφθη was seen with all his forces, Plu. Them. 12, cf. Id. Sull. 12; ἁ. λεγόμενον used in a collective sense, opp. κατὰ μέρος, Pl. Tht. 182a; ἀθρόας γινομένης μεταβολῆς taking place all at once, Arist. Ph. 186a15; opp. ἐκ προσαγωγῆς, Id. Pol. 1308b16; κατήριπεν ἀ. he fell all at once, Theoc. 13.50, cf. 25.252; ἀθρόαι πέντε νύκτες five whole nights, Pi. P. 4.130; κατάστασις ἀθρόα καὶ αἰσθητή Arist. Rh. 1369b34; κάθαρσις ἀ., opp. κατʼ ὀλίγον, Id. HA 582b7; καταπιεῖν ἅθρους τεμαχίτας at a gulp, Eub. 9, cf. Plu. QConv. 2.650c, etc.; ἀθρόον ἐκκαγχάζειν burst out laughing, Arist. EN 1150b11, cf. Hp. Ep. 17.

P. 5.18; but -έστατος . . χρυσός O. 3.42, cf. Alcm. 74A. Adv. -ως, ἀπέπεμπον, of a guest, Od. 19.243.

definition: αἰδώς, όος, contr. οῦς, ἡ (late nom. pl. αἰδοί Sch. E. Hipp. 386), as a moral feeling,

children.definition: reverence, awe, respect for the feeling or opinion of others or for oneʼs own conscience, and so shame, self-respect (in full ἑαυτοῦ αἰδώς Hierocl. in CA 9p.433M.), sense of honour, αἰδῶ θέσθʼ ἐνὶ θυμῷ Il. 15.561; ἴσχε γὰρ αἰ. καὶ δέος ib. 657, cf. Sapph. 28, Democr. 179, etc.; αἰ. σωφροσύνης πλεῖστον μετέχει, αἰσχύνης δὲ εὐψυχία Th. 1.84, cf. E. Supp. 911, Arist. EN 1108a32, etc.; αἰδοῖ μειλιχίῃ Od. 8.172; so ἀλλά με κωλύει αἴδως Alc. 55 (Sapphus est versus); ἅμα κιθῶνι ἐκδυομένῳ συνεκδύεται καὶ τὴν αἰδῶ γυνή Hdt. 1.8; δακρύων πένθιμον αἰδῶ tears of grief and shame, A. Supp. 579; αἰ. τίς μʼ ἔχει Pl. Sph. 217d; αἰ. καὶ δίκη Id. Prt. 322c; αἰδοῦς ἐμπίπλασθαι X. Cyr. 1.4.4; sobriety, moderation, Pi. O. 13.115; αἰδῶ λαβεῖν S. Aj. 345.

Lg. 867e (cf. αἰδέομαι II.2).

Pass., αἴθομαι, burn, blaze, Hom. always in part., πυρὸς μένος αἰθομένοιο Il. 6.182, cf. 8.563; αἰ. δαλός 13.320; δαΐδες Od. 7.101, cf. Pi. O. 1.1, Pae. 6.97, E. Hipp. 1279, etc.; after Hom. in other moods, αἴθεται κάλλιστα [τὰ ὀστέα] Hdt. 4.61; αἰθέσθω δὲ πῦρ E. IA 1470; δώματʼ αἴθεσθαι δοκῶν Id. Ba. 624, cf. X. An. 6.3.19: metaph., ἔρωτι αἴθεσθαι X. Cyr. 5.1.16, cf. AP 12.83 ( Mel.); αἴθετο . . ἔρως ( Ep. impf.) burnt fiercely, A.R. 3.296. (Cf. Lat. aestas, aestus: the weak form of the root appears in ἰθαίνεσθαι, cf. Skt. inddhé ‘kindles’.)
fiery, burning, κεραυνός Pi. O. 10(11).83; of fiery smoke, P. 1.23.

children.label: II

children.label: III

data.ref: Pl. R. 559d); pr. n. of horse,

Eq. 48; τὰ μὲν λόγιʼ αἰκάλλει με flatter, please me, ib. 211; αἰκάλλει καρδίαν ἐμήν it cheers my heart. Id. Th. 869; τοὺς περὶ τὴν αὐλήν Plb. 5.36.1, cf. Axiop. 3.4, Philostr. VA 5.42:— Pass., ὑπό τινων Plb. 15.25.31:—of a fox, σεσηρὸς αἰκάλλουσα wagging the tail fawningly, Babr. 50.14.—Trag., Com., and later Prose.

Ax. 372a: pf. ᾔκισμαι D.S. 18.47, Polyaen. 8.6: more freq. in aor. 1, πρὸς κυνῶν ἐδεστὸν αἰκισθέντα S. Ant. 206; ἐδέθη καὶ ᾐκίσθη Lys. 6.27; τὰ σφέτερα αὐτῶν σώματα αἰκισθέντες And. 1.138, cf. Aj. 111, OT 1153, Isoc. 5.103, X. An. 3.4.5: pf. ᾔκισμαι E. Med. 1130, plpf. ᾔκιστο Plu. Caes. 29:—in same sense as Act., ll. cc.; damage, τὰ χωρία D. 43.72: c. dupl. acc. pers. et rei, αἰκίζεσθαί τινα τὰ ἔσχατα X. An. 3.1.18; αἰκίσασθαί τινας πᾶσαν αἰκίαν Plb. 24.9.13.
outrage, torture, A. Pr. 989, Lys. 6.26:— in pl. -ίσματα νεκρῶν mutilated corpses, E. Ph. 1529.

definition: αἰκίστρια, ἡ (as if from a masc. αἰκιστής),

Adj., αἴλινος, ον, mournful, plaintive, αἰλίνοις κακοῖς E. Hel. 171; βρέφος αἴ. unhappy, IG 14.1502: neut. pl. αἴλινα as Adv., Call. Ap. 20, Mosch. 3.1: hence αἰλινέω sing a dirge, cj. in Dosiad. Ara 15.

definition: αἰλούριος, ὁ, ῥίζα τις, Hsch., EM 34.9.

blood, Il. 1.303, etc.; φόνος αἵματος 16.162; ψυχῆς ἄκρατον αἷμα S. El. 786: in pl., streams of blood, A. Ag. 1293, S. Ant. 121, E. El. 1172, Alc. 496.

Fr. 799.3; αἷμα τραγοκτόνον shedding of goatʼs blood, E. Ba. 139; ἐφʼ αἵματι φεύγειν to avoid trial for murder by going into exile, SIG 58 (Milet., V B.C.), D. 21.105; αἷμα συγγενὲς φεύγων E. Supp. 148: pl. in this sense, A. Ch. 66, 650, freq. in E., never in S.; αἵματα σύγγονα brothers’ corpses, E. Ph. 1502:—concrete, νεακόνητον αἷ. keen-edged death, i. e. a sword, S. El. 1394 (expl. by μάχαιρα, Hsch.).

gush, stream of blood, S. Ph. 695 (lyr.).

definition: αἰνέω (cf. αἴνημι, αἰνίζομαι), impf. ᾔνουν E. Hec. 1154, Ion. αἴνεον Hdt. 3.73: fut. αἰνήσω Od. 16.380, Thgn. 1080, Pi. N. 1.72; in Att. Poets always αἰνέσω, as in Pi. N. 7.63, Semon. 7.112: aor. ᾔνησα Hom., opt. αἰνήσειε Simon. 57.1; Dor. αἴνησα Pi. P. 3.13; in Att. always ᾔνεσα, Ion. αἴνεσα Hdt. 5.113: pf.ᾔνεκα ( ἐπ-) Isoc. 12.207:— Med., fut. αἰνέσομαι (only in compds. ἐπ-, παρ-):— Pass., aor. part. αἰνεθείς Hdt. 5.102: pf.ᾔνημαι ( ἐπ-) Hp. Acut. 51, Isoc. 12.233.—Poet. and Ion. Verb, very rare in good Att. Prose ( Pl. R. 404d, Lg. 952c), ἐπαινέω being used instead:—

approve, advise, recommend Od. 16.380, 403: c. inf., recommend to do a thing, euphem. for κελεύω, A. Ch. 555, 715 : c. part., αἰνεῖν ἰόντα to commend oneʼs going, Id. Pers. 643:—ὦ δεινὸν αἶνον αἰνέσας giver of dire counsel, S. Ph. 1380:— c. acc. rei, to be content with, acquiesce in, γάμον Pi. P. 3.13, cf. N. 1.72, A. Eu. 469, Supp. 902, 1070 (lyr.), E. Med. 1157; θῆσσαν τράπεζαν αἰνέσαι Id. Alc. 2.
praise, with collateral sense, decline courteously, νῇ ὀλίγην αἰνεῖν, μεγάλῃ δʼ ἐνὶ φορτία θέσθαι Hes. Op. 643 (cf. Plu. Aud.poet. 2.22f), cf. S. Fr. 109; but, thank, cj. in E. Supp. 388.

data.quote: νῇ ὀλίγην αἰνεῖν, μεγάλῃ δʼ ἐνὶ φορτία θέσθαι

El. 946: c. acc. cogn., λόγον . . αἰνίξατο Pi. P. 8.40; αἰνίσσεσθαι ἔπεα to speak riddling verses, Hdt. 5.56: c. acc. rei, hint a thing, intimate, shadow forth, Pl. Ap. 21b, Tht. 152c; τὸ δίκαιον ὃ εἴη R. 332b; ὅτι . . Phd. 69c; αἰ. εἰς . . to refer as in a riddle to, to hint at, εἰς Κλέωνα τοῦτʼ αἰνίττεται Ar. Pax 47; τὴν Κυλλήνην . . εἰς τὴν χεῖρʼ ὀρθῶς ᾐνίξατο used the riddling word Cyllene (cf. κυλλός) . ., Id. Eq. 1085; so ᾐνίξαθʼ ὁ Βάκις τοῦτο πρὸς τὸν ἀέρα Id. Av. 970; αἰνιττόμενος εἰς ἐμέ Aeschin. 2.108; αἰ. ὡς . . Ps.-Plu. Vit.Hom. 4:— αἰ. τὸν ὠκεανόν form guesses about it, Arist. Mete. 347a6.

Aeolian; pl. Αἰολέες Hdt. 1.28, Att. Αἰολεῖς or -ῆς Th. 7.57:—hence Adj. Αἰολικός, ή, όν, of or like the Aeolians, Theoc. 1.56 (v.l.); of the Aeolic dialect, A.D. Adv. 193.15, al.: Comp. -ώτερον 194.8; of Aeolic metre, Heph. 7.5. Adv. -κῶς S.E. M. 1.78:— Αἰόλιος, α, ον, in the Aeolian mode, νόμος Plu. Mus. 2.1132d:—fem. Αἰολίς, ίδος, Hes. Op. 636, Hdt., etc.; of the Aeolian mode, Pratin. 5; of the Aeolic dialect, A.D. Adv. 155.11: Subst., Αἰολίς, ἡ, Id. Synt. 309.25: poet. fem. Αἰοληΐς, Pi. O. 1.102.
Pl. Cra. 409a.
rapid motion, Sch. Pi. P. 4.412.
a speckled fish, Epich. 44, Pl.Com. 173.13; as Adj., αἰολίην κορακῖνον Numen. ap. Ath. 7.308e.
trick out with false words, μηδʼ αἰόλιζε ταῦτα S. Fr. 912.

children.label: II
children.definition: Αἰολεύς) compose in the Aeolian mode, αἰ. τῷ μέλει Pratin. 5; speak Aeolic, Dicaearch. 3.2, Str. 8.1.2, Plu. Cim. 1; αἰολίζεται τὰ Ἀλκαίου ποιήματα A.D. Synt. 279.52.

children.label: III
children.definition: Menecl. 8, cf. Hsch.
varied tones, λύρας S. Ichn. 319.
in the Aeolic dialect, Str. 8.1.2.
to shift rapidly to and fro, ὡς δʼ ὅτε γαστέρʼ ἀνὴρ . . αἰόλλῃ Od. 20.27.

data.quote: ὡς δʼ ὅτε γαστέρʼ ἀνὴρ . . αἰόλλῃ

children.label: II
children.definition: variegate, Nic. Th. 155:— Pass., shift colour, ὄμφακες αἰόλλονται Hes. Sc. 399.
wily, Opp. C. 3.449, al.
wielder of the flashing thunderbolt, Ζεὺς αἰ. Pi. O. 9.42.
with glistening tears, Nonn. D. 26.79, 43.365.
showing himself in various forms, of Phoebus; voc. αἰολόδεικτα, cj. for -δικτε, Orph. H. 8.12.
with sheeny neck, Ibyc. 8, cf. Opp. C. 2.317, Nonn. D. 12.76, al.
bestowing various gifts, Epimenid. 19.
with glancing breastplate, Il. 4.489, Hymn.Mag. 2(2).16.
full of various wiles, like αἰολόβουλος, Hes. Th. 511, A. Supp. 1036 (lyr.); also αἰολο-μήτης, ου, ὁ, Hes. Fr. 7 (s.v.l.).
with glittering girdle, Il. 5.707.

children.label: II
children.definition: with variegated mitre or turban, Theoc. 17.19.
of varied strain, σῦριγξ Nonn. D. 40.223.
of changeful form, Orph. H. 4.7, etc.
with spangled back, Opp. H. 1.125.
with spangled robe, Nonn. D. 7.173.
with gleaming stern, νῆες B. 1.4.
quick-fluttering, Telest. 1.12 (dub.).
with quick-moving steeds, Il. 3.185, h.Ven. 137, Theoc. 22.34.

definition: αἰόλος, η, ον, ( ος, ον Arist. Pr., v. infr.)

children.definition: quick-moving, nimble, πόδας αἰόλος ἵππος Il. 19.404; αἰόλαι εὐλαί wriggling worms, 22.509; σφῆκες μέσον αἰ. 12.167; ὄφις ib. 208; οἶστρος Od. 22.300, cf. Achae. 48.

glittering, τεύχεα Il. 5.295; σάκος 7.222, 16.107; κνώδων S. Aj. 1025:—generally, changeful of hue, sheeny, δράκων Id. Tr. 11; αἰόλα νύξ star-spangled night, ib. 94 (lyr.); αἰ. πυρὸς κάσις smoke flushed by fire-light, A. Th. 494; κύων αἰ. speckled, Call. Dian. 91, etc.; αἰόλα σάρξ discoloured, S. Ph. 1157 (lyr.); ὀφθαλμοί Adam. 1.8, cf. 11.

chequered, αἰόλʼ ἀνθρώπων κακά A. Supp. 328; changeful, ἰαχή E. Ion 499 (lyr.); χορεία Ar. Ra. 248 (lyr.); νόμος Telest. 2; αἰόλα φωνέων Theoc. 16.44; αἰόλοι ἡμέραι changeable days, Arist. Pr. 941b24.
shifty, slippery, ἔπος Sol. 11.7; ψεῦδος Pi. N. 8.25; κέρδεσσι B. 14.57; μηχάνημα λυγκὸς αἰολώτερον Trag.Adesp. 349.—Chiefly poet.

children.label: B
children.definition: Αἴολος, ου, ὁ, the lord of the winds, properly the Rapid or the Changeable, Od., etc.
Nic. Thyat. ap. Ath. 7.320c.
Pythag., = 4, or ἐνιαυτός, Theol.Ar. 22.
shifting in speech, of an oracle, A. Pr. 661.
subject to changeful madness, Sch. Opp. H. 2.420.
of divers kinds, Opp. H. 1.617.
with changeful notes, ἀηδών Opp. H. 1.728.
with parti-coloured hair, Eust. 1645.5.
spangled, νύξ Critias 19.4 D.
moisten, foment, Hp. Nat.Mul. 44: fut. αἰονήσω BKT 3.20: aor. 1 ᾐόνησα A. Fr. 425:— Med., Lyc. 1425.
fomentation, D.C. 55.17, EM 348.27.
fomenting, Hp. Liqu. 1, Poll. 4.180, Gal. 10.781.

definition: αἰπεινός, ή, όν, ( αἰπύς) poet. Adj.

children.definition: high, lofty, of cities on heights, Ἴλιον Il. 9.419, al., cf. A. Fr. 284, S. Tr. 858 (lyr.), Ph. 1000; αἰθήρ B. 8.34; of Delphi, μαντεῖα E. Ion 739; of mountain-tops, κάρηνα Il. 2.869, Od. 6.123.
hasty, wicked words, Pi. N. 5.32.
hard to reach, σοφίαι μὲν αἰ. Id. O. 9.108.

definition: αἰπήεις, εσσα, εν, = foreg., Il. 21.87, A.R. 2.721, AP 7.273 ( Leon.).
αἰπολέω, only in pres. and impf.,

children.definition: tend goats, Eup. 13, Theoc. 8.85; ᾐπόλει ταῖς αἰξίν Lys. Fr. 25:— Pass., ἄνευ βοτῆρος αἰπολούμεναι a flock tended by no herdsman, A. Eu. 196.
of or for goatherds, θάημα Theoc. 1.56; τρύπανον Call. Fr. 412; σύριγγες AP 12.128 ( Mel.), cf. 9.217 (Muc. Scaev.).
herd of goats, αἰπόλιʼ αἰγῶν Il. 11.679, al., cf. Hdt. 1.126, S. Aj. 375 (lyr.), LXX Pr. 24.66 ( 30.31).

children.label: II
children.definition: goat-pasture, AP 9.101 ( Alph.).
goatherd, αἰπόλος αἰγῶν Od. 20.173, cf. Hdt. 2.46, Pl. Lg. 639a, LXX Am. 7.14.

children.label: II
children.definition: Cypr.), Hsch.

height, steep, A. Ag. 285, 309, etc.; πρὸς αἶπος ὁδοιπορῆσαι, ἰέναι to toil up- hill, Hp. Morb. 2.51, 70; πρὸς αἶπος ἔρχεται, metaph. of a difficult task, E. Alc. 500: hence αἶ. (v.l. ἆπος ) ἐκβαλὼν ὁδοῦ, i.e. the weariness of the ascent (expl. by Hsch. as κάματος), Id. Ph. 851 (unless ἐκβαλών = ‘forgettingʼ).

data.ref: 309, etc.; πρὸς αἶπος ὁδοιπορῆσαι, ἰέναι to toil up-
70; πρὸς αἶπος ἔρχεται, metaph. of a difficult task,
E. Alc. 500: hence αἶ. (v.l. ἆπος ) ἐκβαλὼν ὁδοῦ, i.e. the

children.definition: high, lofty, of cities, Il. 13.625, al.; αἰπὰ ῥέεθρα streams falling sheer down, Il. 8.369, Hes. Oxy. 1358.2.23: αἰπόν, τό, dub. in Ath.Mitt. 31.138 ( Athens).
high-built, Coluth. 235, Nonn. D. 4.13.
EM 37.38, Suid.
high-crested, Nonn. D. 2.379, etc.
with high thoughts, Θέμιδος αἰπυμῆτα παῖ A. Pr. 18.

definition: αἰπύνοος, ον, = foreg., of Osiris, Hymn.Is. 19.

children.definition: on a high mountain-ridge, of Dodona, A. Pr. 830.
high-roaming, Man. 4.249.

definition: αἰπύς, εῖα, ύ, Ep. and Lyr. Adj., rare in Trag.,

children.definition: high and steep, in Hom. mostly of cities on rocky heights, esp. of Troy, Od. 3.485, al.; of hills, Il. 2.603; later of the sky, αἰθήρ B. 3.36; οὐρανός S. Aj. 845; on high, ποδῶν αἰ. ἰωή Hes. Th. 682; ἁψαμένη βρόχον αἰπύν hanging high, Od. 11.278.

sheer, utter, αἰ. ὄλεθρος freq. in Hom., death being regarded as the plunge from a high precipice; φόνος αἰ. Od. 4.843; θάνατος Pi. O. 10(11).42; σκότος utter darkness, Id. Fr. 228; of passions, etc., αἰ. χόλος towering wrath, Il. 15.223; δόλος αἰ. h.Merc. 66, Hes. Th. 589; αἰπυτάτη σοφίη AP 11.354 ( Agath.); arduous, πόνος Il. 11.601, 16.651; αἰπύ οἱ ἐσσεῖται ʼtwill be hard work for him, 13.317.
hammer, αἰράων ἔργα smithʼs work, Call. Fr. 129.
Hsch.

children.label: II
children.definition: darnel, Lolium temulentum, Thphr. HP 1.5.2: in pl., Ar. Fr. 412, Pherecr. 188, Arist. Somn.Vig. 456b30, Herod. 6.100, etc.
dues paid on discharge of cargoes, IG 11(2).203 A 30 ( Delos, iii B. C.), al.
dominate the ‘condition’, Rhetor. in Cat.Cod.Astr. 1.146.
leader of a school, S.E. P. 3.245; esp. of a medical school, IG 14.1759, Gal. 6.372; heresiarch, Just. Nov. 42.1.1 (pl.).

data.ref: S.E. P. 3.245; esp. of a medical school,

children.label: II
children.definition: dominating the ‘condition’ (cf. αἵρεσις B. II.4), Paul.Al. R. 3. [p 91 Boer]
that can be taken, X. Cyr. 5.2.4.
fighting for a sect, Ph. 2.84.

taking, esp. of a town, Hdt. 4.1, etc.; ἡ βασιλέος αἵ. the taking by the king, Id. 9.3; ἐλπίζων ταχίστην -σιν ἔσεσθαι Th. 2.75; αἵ. δυνάμεως acquisition of power, Pl. Grg. 513a:—generally, taking, receiving, ἐπιγενημάτων PTeb. 27.66 (ii B. C.).

children.label: B
children.definition: αἱρέομαι) choice, αἵρεσίν τʼ ἐμοὶ δίδου A. Pr. 779; τῶνδε . . αἵρεσιν παρδίδωμι Pi. N. 10.82; foll. by relat., αἵ. διδόναι ὁκοτέρην . . , εἰ . . , etc., Hdt. 1.11, cf. D. 22.19; αἵ. προτιθέναι, προβάλλειν, Pl. Tht. 196c, Sph. 245b; εἰ νέμοι τις αἵρεσιν S. Aj. 265; αἵρεσιν λαβεῖν D. 36.11; ποιεῖσθαι Isoc. 7.19; αἵ. γίγνεταί τινι Th. 2.61; οὐκ ἔχει αἵρεσιν it admits no choice, Plu. QConv. 2.708b.
choice, election of magistrates, Th. 8.89, cf. Arist. Pol. 1266a26, al.; αἱρέσει, opp. κλήρῳ, 1300a19, etc.

data.ref: Arist. Pol. 1266a26, al.; αἱρέσει, opp. κλήρῳ,

children.definition: inclination, choice, πρός τινα Philipp. ap. D. 18.166, Plb. 2.61.9, etc., cf. IG 2.591b; opp. φυγή, Epicur. Ep. 3p.62U.; περὶ αἱρέσεων καὶ φυγῶν, title of treatise by Epicurus.

data.ref: Epicur. Ep. 3p.62U.; περὶ αἱρέσεων καὶ φυγῶν, title of treatise by Epicurus.

children.label: II
children.definition: purpose, course of action or thought, like προαίρεσις, Pl. Phdr. 256c; ἡ αἵ. τῆς πρεσβείας Aeschin. 2.11; αἵ. Ἐλληνική the study of Greek literature, Plb. 39.1.3:— conduct, PTeb. 28.10 (ii B. C.).

system of philosophic principles, or those who profess such principles, sect, school, Plb. 5.93.8, D.S. 2.29, Polystr. p.20 W., D.H. Amm. 1.7, Comp. 2, al., cf. Cic. Fam. 15.16.3; κατὰ τῶν αἱ., title of treatise by Antipater of Tarsus; περὶ αἱρέσεων, title of Menippean satire by Varro, cf. Fr. 164; αἵρεσις πρὸς Γοργιππίδην, title of work by Chrysippus, D.L. 7.191; esp. religious party or sect, of the Essenes, J. BJ 2.8.1; the Sadducees and Pharisees, Act.Ap. 5.17, 15.5, 26.5; the Christians, ib. 24.5, 14, 28.22, generally, faction, party, App. BC 5.2.

data.ref: Cic. Fam. 15.16.3; κατὰ τῶν αἱ., title of treatise by Antipater of Tarsus; περὶ αἱρέσεων, title of Menippean satire by
Fr. 164; αἵρεσις πρὸς Γοργιππίδην, title of work by Chrysippus,
J. BJ 2.8.1; the Sadducees and Pharisees,

children.definition: corps of epheboi, OGI 176 ( Egypt).
‘condition’, Ptol. Tetr. 21; ἡ ἡμερινὴ αἵ. Vett.Val. 1.13.

children.label: III
children.definition: proposed condition, proposal, D.H. 3.10.
commission, ἡ ἐπὶ τοὺς νέους αἵ. Pl. Ax. 367a; embassy, mission, IG 4.937 (Epid.).
freewill offering, opp. vow, LXX Le. 22.18, al.
bid at auction, τὴν ἀμείνονα αἵ. διδόντι παραδοθῆναι POxy. 716.22 (ii A. D.), cf. 1630.8 (iii A. D.).
member of a sect, Porph. Abst. 4.11 (v.l. αἱρετισταῖς): —fem. αἱρεσι-ῶτις, πολιτεία Suid.
to be chosen, ὠφελήματα, opp. αἱρετὰ ἀγαθά, Chrysipp.Stoic. 3.22, 61, al.

children.label: II
children.definition: one must choose, Pl. Grg. 499e, Phld. Rh. 1.287S., etc.
searcher of archives, αἱ. ἡγεμονικῆς βιβλιοθήκης POxy. 1654.7 (ii A. D.).

children.label: II
children.definition: αἱρέομαι) one who chooses, ἀγαθῶν Vett.Val. 55.17.
Ptol. Tetr. 96.

choose, τινά Com. ap. Phot. p.54 R., cf. Hp. Ep. 17, LXX Ge. l.c., Babr. 61.5; ᾑρέτικα ἐν αὐτῷ εἶναί μου υἱόν 1 Ch. 28.6; ᾑρέτικέ σε οἰκοδομῆσαι ib. 10; αἱρετίσας πατήρ adoptive father, IPE 2.299 (Panticap.): abs., αἱρετίσαντος τοῦ θεοῦ IG 3.74:— Med., LXX Ps. 118(119).30, al., Aesop. 53, Ctes. Fr. 29.9.

data.quote: ᾑρέτικα ἐν αὐτῷ εἶναί μου υἱόν

children.definition: able to choose, Pl. Def. 412a; due to choice, οἰκείωσις Hierocl. p.41.5A., Anon. in Tht. 7.40.
factious, Ep.Tit. 3.10.
belonging to the ‘condition’, Paul.Al. Q. 2 [85 Boer?].
Adv. -κῶς from choice, D.L. 7.126, Hierocl. p.41.7 A.
one who chooses, LXX Wi. 8.4.
one who chooses, τινός Plb. 22.6.11.
partisan, τῶν τρόπων τινός Philem. 131, cf. Plb. 1.79.9, etc.; founder of a philosophical school, D.L. 9.6; τῶν λόγων Vit.Philonid. p.12 C.
sectarian, J. BJ 2.8.2, Iamb. Protr. 21.κά.
belonging to the ‘condition’, Jul.Laod. in Cat.Cod.Astr. 5(1).183.
that may be taken or conquered, δόλῳ Hdt. 4.201; to be understood, Pl. Phd. 81b.

children.label: II
children.definition: αἱρέομαι) to be chosen, eligible, opp. φευκτός, Pl. Phlb. 21d sq., Arist. EN 1097a32, etc.: freq. in Comp. or Sup., Hdt. 1.126, 156, al.; ζόης πονηρᾶς θάνατος αἱρετώτερος A. Fr. 401.

chosen, elected, esp. opp. κληρωτός, Isoc. 12.154, Pl. Lg. 759b, Arist. Pol. 1294b9, cf. Pl. Lg. 915c, Aeschin. 3.13; αἱ. βασιλῆς Pl. Mx. 238d; τυραννίς Arist. Pol. 1285a31:—αἱ. ἄνδρες commissioners, Plu. Lyc. 26. οἱ αἱ. X. An. 1.3.21: = Lat. optiones, Lyd. Mag. 1.46.
that may be chosen, opp. αἱρετέος (q.v.), Chrysipp.Stoic. 3.22.

definition: αἱρέω, impf. ᾕρεον Il. 24.579, Ion. αἵρεον Hdt. 6.31, but contr. ᾕρει even in Il. 17.463, ᾕρευν Hes. Sc. 302: fut. αἱρήσω Il. 9.28, etc.: aor. 1 ᾕρησα late ( ἀν-) Q.S. 4.40, etc.: pf. ᾕρηκα A. Ag. 267, Th. 1.61, etc., Ion. ἀραίρηκα or αἵρηκα ( ἀν-) Hdt. 5.102: plpf. ἀραιρήκεε 3.39:— Med., fut. αἱρήσομαι Il. 10.235, etc.: aor. 1 ᾑρησάμην Plb. 38.13.7 s. v.l., Gal. 19.53, etc.: pf. in med. sense ᾕρημαι Ar. Av. 1577, X. An. 5.6.12, D. 2.15, etc.: 3 pl. plpf. ᾕρηντο Th. 1.62:— Pass., fut. αἱρεθήσομαι Hdt. 2.13, Pl. Mx. 234b; rarely ᾑρήσομαι Id. Prt. 338c: aor. ᾑρέθην and pf. ᾕρημαι D. 20.146, al.; pf. part. ἀραιρημένος Hdt. 4.66: plpf. ᾕρηντο X. An. 3.2.1, ἀραίρητο Hdt. 1.191, etc.—From √ἑλ-: fut. ἑλῶ only late ( δι-) Test.Epict. 6.18, ( ἀν-) D.H. 11.18, ( καθ-) APl. 16.334 ( Antiphil.): aor.1 εἷλα ( ἀν-) Act.Ap. 2.23, ( ἀν-) Epigr.Gr. 314.24 ( Smyrna): elsewh. aor.2 εἷλον Il. 10.561, etc., Ep. ἕλον 17.321, Ion. ἕλεσκε 24.752:— Med., fut. ἑλοῦμαι D.H. 4.75, ( ἀφ-) Timostr. 5, ( δι-) D.H. 4.60, ( ἐξ-) Alciphr. 1.9: aor. 1 εἱλάμην Epigr.Gr. 314.5 ( Smyrna), ( ἀφ-) v.l. in Ath. 12.546a, ( δι-) AP 9.56 ( Phil.): elsewh. aor. 2 εἱλόμην Il. 16.139, etc., 2 sg. ἤλεο Sapph. Oxy. 1787.6.3:—Cret. forms αἰλεθῇ Leg.Gort. 2.21, ἀν-αιλῆθαι ib. 7.10, al.:—the etym. is doubtful, and ἀγρέω (q.v.) prob. has a difft. root.

children.label: A
children.definition: Act., take with the hand, grasp, seize, αἱ. τι ἐν χερσίν Od. 4.66; αἱ. τινὰ χειρός to take one by the hand, Il. 1.323; κόμης τινά ib. 197; μʼ ἑλὼν ἐπὶ μάστακα χερσίν Od. 23.76: part.ἑλών adverbially, κατακτεῖναί μʼ ἑλών S. Ant. 497; ἄξω ἑλών Il. 1.139, cf. Pi. O. 7.1; but ἔνθεν ἑλών having taken up [the song], Od. 8.500.
take away, ἀπʼ ἀπήνης ᾕρεον ἄποινα Il. 24.579.

children.label: II
children.definition: take, get into oneʼs power, νῆας ib. 13.42; esp. take a city, 2.37, S. Ph. 347, etc.; overpower, kill, Il. 4.457, etc.; ἕλοιμί κεν ἤ κε ἁλοίην 22.253:—freq. of passions, etc., come upon, seize, χόλος Il. 18.322; ἵμερος 3.446; ὕπνος 10.193; λήθη 2.34, etc.: c. dupl.acc., τὸν δʼ ἄτη φρένας εἷλε 16.805; of disease, Pl. Tht. 142b.

catch, take, ζωὸν ἑλεῖν Il. 21.102; take in hunting, Hes. Sc. 302, Hdt. 1.36, etc.; overtake, in a race, Il. 23.345; get into oneʼs power, entrap, S. OC 764, etc.; in good sense, win over, X. Mem. 2.3.16, cf. 3.11.11, Pl. Ly. 205e, etc.

data.ref: S. OC 764, etc.; in good sense,

children.label: b
children.definition: part., catch, detect one doing a thing, S. Ant. 385, 655; ἐπʼ αὐτοφώρῳ ἑλεῖν E. Ion 1214; φῶρα ἐπὶ κλοπῇ ἑλεῖν Pl. Lg. 874b.

win, gain, κῦδος Il. 17.321; στεφάνους Pi. P. 3.74, etc.; esp. in games, Ἴσθμιʼ ἑλὼν πύξ Simon. 158; with double sense, overcome and win, ἑλέτην δίφρον τε καὶ ἀνέρε Il. 11.328; ἕλεν Οἰνομάου βίαν παρθένον τε σύνευνον Pi. O. 1.88, cf. S. Tr. 353:— Pass., ἁγὼν ᾑρέθη the fight was won, S. OC 1148.

data.quote: ἕλεν Οἰνομάου βίαν παρθένον τε σύνευνον

children.label: b
children.definition: get, obtain, Pl. R. 359a, Ti. 64b, etc.

convict, τινά τινος Ar. Nu. 591, Is. 9.36, Aeschin. 3.156; εἷλέ σʼ ἡ Δίκη E. Heracl. 941, cf. Supp. 608: c. part., αἱ. τινὰ κλέπτοντα to convict of theft, Ar. Eq. 829, Pl. Lg. 941d; ᾑρῆσθαι κλοπεύς (sc. ὤν) S. Ant. 493, cf. 406.

children.label: b
children.definition: get a verdict for conviction, Antipho 2.1.5, etc.; also ἑλεῖν τινα obtain a conviction against one, Is. 7.13; ἑλεῖν τὰ διαμαρτυρηθέντα convict the evidence of falsehood, Isoc. 18.15.

children.label: c
children.definition: get a conviction, οἱ ἑλόντες, opp. οἱ ἑαλωκότες, D. 21.11; δολίοις ἕλε Κύπρις λόγοις Aphrodite won her cause . . , E. Andr. 289, cf. Pl. Lg. 762b, etc.

data.ref: D. 21.11; δολίοις ἕλε Κύπρις λόγοις Aphrodite

children.label: d
children.definition: convict, τοῦτʼ ἔστιν ὃ ἐμὲ αἱρεῖ Id. Ap. 28a.

proves, Hdt. 2.33: c. acc. pers., reason persuades one, i.e. it seems good to one, Id. 1.132, 7.41; ὡς ἐμὴ γνώμη αἱ. Hdt. 2.43; ὅπῃ ὁ λόγος αἱ. βέλτιστʼ ἂν ἔχειν Pl. R. 604c, cf. Lg. 663d: c. inf., R. 440b; ὁ αἱρῶν λόγος Chrysipp.Stoic. 3.92; αἱρεῖ alone, proves, Plu. QConv. 2.651b.

Ph. 75, etc.; hear, βοήν Id. Aj. 1318, cf. Ph. 252; οὐκ εἶδον αὐτόν, ᾐσθόμην δʼ ἔτʼ ὄντα νιν ib. 445; τινὸς ὑποστενούσης αἰ. Id. El. 79; βοῆς E. Hipp. 603, etc.

El. 89, Ph. 252, E. Hel. 653, 764, etc.:—freq. with part. agreeing with subject, αἰσθάνομαι κάμνων Th. 2.51; αἰσθώμεθα γελοῖοι ὄντες Pl. Thg. 122c; agreeing with object, τυράννους ἐκπεσόντας ᾐσθόμην A. Pr. 957, cf. Th. 1.47, etc.; ἤδη τινῶν ᾐσθόμην ἀχθομένων Lys. 16.20, cf. Pl. Ap. 22c; ᾐσθόμην τεχνωμένου Ar. V. 176: less freq. c. acc. et inf., Th. 6.59; αἰ. ὅτι . . Id. 5.2, Pl. Ap. 21e, etc.; ᾔσθετο ὅτι τὸ στράτευμα ἦν . . X. An. 1.2.21; αἰ. ὡς . . ib. 3.1.40, etc.; οὕνεκα . . S. El. 1477:—abs., αἰσθανόμενος having full possession of oneʼs faculties, τῇ ἡλικίᾳ Th. 5.26; sensible, of keen perception, καὶ μετρίως αἰσθανομένῳ φανερόν X. Mem. 4.1.1, cf. Th. 1.71, Pl. R. 360d.—The Pass. is supplied by αἴσθησιν παρέχω, cf. αἴσθησις I.

sense-perception, sensation, Philol. 13, Archyt. 1, Arist. APo. 99b35; τοῦ σώματος ἡ αἴ. Hp. VM 9; πρὸς αἴσθησιν perceptibly, Ptol. Alm. 1.10, etc.: in pl., the senses, Democr. 9, al.; διʼ ἑπτὰ σχημάτων αἱ αἰ. Hp. Vict. 1.23, cf. Pl. Tht. 156b, etc.: in sg. of the several senses, ἡ τοῦ ὁρᾶν αἴ. Id. R. 507e; ἀπʼ ὄψεως ἤ τινος ἄλλῃς αἰ. Id. Phlb. 39b; organ or seat of sensation, X. Mem. 1.4.6; πάσα, τὰς αἰ. ἐν τῇ κεφαλῇ εἶναι Arist. Fr. 95, cf. Pr. 958b16; αἴ. πημάτων perception, sense of . . , E. El. 290; esp. of pain, Vett.Val. 113.10. al.; also of the mind, perception, knowledge of a thing, ἐν αἰ. γενέσθαι τινός Plu. Luc. 11, etc.; αἴ. ἔχειν τινός, = αἰσθάνεσθαί τινος, have a perception of a thing, Pl. Ap. 40c; περὶ ὑμῶν Tht. 192b; πᾶσαν αἴσθησιν αἰσθάνεσθαι Phdr. 240d; λαμβάνειν Isoc. 1.47; ἐν αἰ. εἶναι Plot. 4.7.15:—also of things, αἴσθησιν ἔχειν give a perception, i.e. become perceptible, serving as Pass. to αἰσθάνομαι, Th. 2.61; more freq. αἴσθησιν παρέχειν Id. 3.22, X. An. 4.6.13, etc.; αἴ. ποιῆσαί τινι Antipho 5.44, cf. D. 10.7; αἴ. παρέχειν τινός furnish the means of observing, Th. 2.50; αἴ. ἐγένετο περί τινος D. 48.16.

Pr. 837, S. OC 890, etc., part. ᾄξαντες Is. 4.10; Ion. ἀΐξασκον Il. 23.369:— Med., aor. ἀΐξασθαι Il. 22.195:— Pass., Hom.: aor. ἠίχθην, ἀΐχθην Il. Hipp. 1351 :—of one darting upon his enemy, ἀΐσσειν ἔγχει, φασγάνῳ, ἵπποις, Il. 11.484, 5.81, 17.460, etc.; τοῖσιν (sc. σκήπτροισιν) 18.506; of the rapid flight of birds, 23.868, etc.; ἤιξεν πέτεσθαι 21.247; of ghosts gliding about, τοὶ δὲ σκιαὶ ἀΐσσουσιν Od. 10.495; of javelins, Il. 5.657; of a tree, shoot up, Pi. N. 8.40; of veins, etc., in the body, Hp. Epid. 2.4.1, cf. Morb. 4.54: c. acc. cogn., ἦξαν δράμημα E. Ph. 1379; κέλευθον A. Pr. 837: once in aor. Med., ἀντίον ἀΐξασθαι Il. 22.195 : also in Pass., [ ἔγχος] ὦσεν . . ἐτώσιον ἀϊχθῆναι Il. 5.854; ἐς οὐρανὸν ἀϊχθήτην 24.97; ἐκ χειρῶν ἡνία ἠίχθησαν slipped from his hands, 16.404; ἀμφὶ δὲ χαῖται ὤμοις ἀΐσσονται 6.510; κόμη διʼ αὔρας . . ᾄσσεται S. OC 1261; shoot forth, of limbs, Emp. 29 :— Act., to be driven, πνευμάτων ὑπὸ δυσχίμων ἀΐσσω E. Supp. 962.

responsibility, mostly in bad sense, guilt, blame, or the imputation thereof, i.e. accusation, first in Pi. O. 1.35 and Hdt., v. infr. ( Hom. uses αἴτιος):—Phrases: αἰτίαν ἔχειν bear responsibility for, τινός A. Eu. 579, S. Ant. 1312; but usu. to be accused, τινός of a crime, φόνου Hdt. 5.70: c. inf., Ar. V. 506; foll. by ὡς . . , Pl. Ap. 38c; by ὡς c. part., Id. Phdr. 249d; ὑπό τινος by some one, A. Eu. 99, Pl. R. 565b: reversely, αἰτία ἔχει τινά Hdt. 5.70, 71; αἰ. φεύγειν τινός S. Ph. 1404; ἐν αἰτίᾳ εἶναι or γίγνεσθαι, Hp. Art. 67, X. Mem. 2.8.6; αἰτίαν ὑπέχειν lie under a charge, Pl. Ap. 33b, X. Cyr. 6.3.16; ὑπομεῖναι Aeschin. 3.139; φέρεσθαι Th. 2.60; λαβεῖν ἀπό τινος ib. 18; αἰτίαις ἐνέχεσθαι Pl. Cri. 52a; αἰτίαις περιπίπτειν Lys. 7.1; εἰς αἰτίαν ἐμπίπτειν Pl. OT 656; τὴν αἰτίαν ἐπιφέρειν τινί impute the fault to one, Hdt. 1.26; αἰτίαν νέμειν τινί S. Aj. 28; ἐπάγειν D. 18.283; προσβάλλειν τινί Antipho 3.2.4; ἀνατιθέναι, προστιθέναι, Hp. VM 21, Ar. definition: αἰτιάομαι, used by Hom. only in Ep. forms, 3 pl. αἰτιόωνται, opt. αἰτιόῳο, -ῳτο, inf. αἰτιάασθαι, impf. ἠτιάασθε, -όωντο: Aeol. impf. 2 sg. αἰτίαο Lyr.Adesp. 66: fut. -άσομαι Ar. Nu. 1433, Pl. Phd. 85d: aor. ᾐτιᾱσάμην E. Fr. 254, Th. 1.120, etc., Ion. -ησάμενος Hdt. 4.94, -ήσασθαι Hp. de Arte 4: pf. ᾐτίᾱμαι D. 19.215, Ion. -ίημαι Hp. Ep. 17 (also in pass. sense, and aor. ᾐτιάθην always so, v. infr. Ι.1): ( αἰτία):—

children.definition: accuse, censure, c. acc. pers., τάχα κεν καὶ ἀναίτιον αἰτιόῳτο Il. 11.654, cf. Od. 20.135; ἀναίτιον αἰτιάασθαι Il. 13.775; θεοὺς βροτοὶ αἰτιόωνται Od. 1.32, cf. E. Fr. 254; καί μʼ τιάασθε ἕκαστος Il. 16.202, cf. S. OT 608, Lys. 7.38, etc.; αἰ. ὡς μιαρούς Pl. R. 562d; αἰ. τινά τινος to accuse of a thing, Hdt. 5.27, Pl. R. 619c, D. 21.104, etc.: c. inf., αἰ. τινὰ ποιεῖν τι accuse one of doing, Hdt. 5.27, Pl. Criti. 120c, X. Mem. 1.1.2; οὐ τὰ ὑμέτερα αἰτιασόμεθα μὴ οὐχ ἕτοιμα εἶναι Pl. La. 189c; αἰ. τινὰ ὡς . . or ὅτι . . , Th. 1.120, X. An. 3.1.7; αἰ. τινὰ περί τινος X. HG 1.7.6: c. acc. cogn., αἰ. αἰτίαν κατά τινος bring a charge against one, Antipho 6.27:— Pass., to be accused, aor. 1 ᾐτιάθην (always) Th. 6.53, 8.68, X. HG 2.1.32: pf. ᾐτίαμαι Th. 3.61: fut. αἰτιαθήσομαι D.C. 37.56.

data.quote: οὐ τὰ ὑμέτερα αἰτιασόμεθα μὴ οὐχ ἕτοιμα εἶναι

children.label: b
children.definition: give one the credit of being, σὲ τίς αἰτιᾶται νομοθέτην ἀγαθὸν γεγονέναι; Pl. R. 599e, cf. 379c, Cra. 396d.
lay to oneʼs charge, impute, τοῦτο αἰ. X. Cyr. 3.1.39; ταῦτα D. 19.215: c. dupl. acc., τί ταῦτα τοὺς Λάκωνας αἰτιώμεθα ; Ar. Ach. 514.
injure, ὁπλήν Hippiatr. 105.

children.label: II
children.definition: allege as the cause, οὐ τὸ αἴτιον αἰ. not to allege the real cause, Pl. R. 329b; τίνα ἔχεις αἰτιάσασθαι . . τούτου κύριον; ib. 508a; φωνάς τε . . καὶ ἄλλα μυρία αἰ. Id. Phd. 98e; τἀναίτια Id. Ti. 88a; ὧν τὴν πενίαν αἰτιάσαιτʼ ἄν τις D. 18.263; τὴν δίνην Arist. Cael. 295a32; τὸ αὐτόματον Id. Ph. 196a25.

data.ref: Pl. R. 329b; τίνα ἔχεις αἰτιάσασθαι . . τούτου κύριον; ib.

data.quote: φωνάς τε . . καὶ ἄλλα μυρία αἰ.
ὧν τὴν πενίαν αἰτιάσαιτʼ ἄν τις

children.definition: inf., allege, τὸν λόγον αἰ. δυσχερῆ εἶναι Pl. Prt. 333d, cf. Men. 93d; αἰ. τι αἴτιον εἶναι Grg. 518d; ἰλίγγους ἐκ φιλοσοφίας ἐγγίγνεσθαι allege by way of accusation that . . , Id. R. 407c; τῆς ἱερᾶς χώρας ᾐτιᾶτο εἶναι he alleged that it was part of . . , D. 18.150, cf. 37.12. (Late in Act., POxy. 1032.51 (ii A. D.).)

data.ref: Id. R. 407c; τῆς ἱερᾶς χώρας ᾐτιᾶτο εἶναι

children.definition: complaint, accusation, Antipho 5.25, Arist. Po. 1455b31, PFlor. 311.4 (v A.D.).
one must accuse, blame, X. Cyr. 7.1.11, Str. 1.2.30.

children.label: II
children.definition: one must allege as the cause, Pl. R. 379c, Ti. 57c, 87b, Arist. Mete. 339a32.
causal, Sch. Il. 23.627.
noxious, τόπος Vett.Val. 208.10.

children.label: II
children.definition: accusative case, indicating the thing caused by the vb., Stoic. 2.59, D.T. 636.6, A.D. Pron. 11.9, etc. Adv. -κῶς in the accusative, Sch. E. Ph. 470.
produced by a cause, effected, Arist. APo. 76a20; τὸ αἰ. effect, opp. τὸ αἴτιον cause, ib. 98a36, Plot. 6.2.3: Comp. -ότερος Eustr. in APo. 40.28.

definition: αἰτίζω, Ep. form of αἰτέω (not in Il., once in Ar.); only pres. (exc. aor. part. αἰτίσσας in AP 10.66 ( Agath.),

children.definition: ask, beg, c. acc. rei, σῖτον . . αἰτίζων κατὰ δῆμον Od. 17.558, cf. 222; ἡνίκʼ ἂν αἰτίζητʼ ἄρτον Ar. Pax 120 (hex.); generally, ask, φέρευ τέκος ὅσσʼ ἐθελημὸς αἰτίζεις Call. Dian. 32.
beg of, αἰτίζειν . . πάντας ἐποιχόμενον μνηστῆρας Od. 17.346.
beg, αἰτίζων βόσκειν ἣν γαστέρα ib. 228, cf. 4.651.

inquire into causes, reason, account for, ὑπὲρ τῶν μετεώρων Epicur. Ep. 1p.31U., cf. Diocl. Fr. 112, Plot. 6.7.3, Plu. QConv. 2.689b; τὸ ζητούμενον Aenesid. ap. S.E. P. 1.181, cf. Demetr.Lac. 1012.68:— Pass., ἐκ τοῦ συνδέσμου ᾐτιολογημένον ἐστίν the conjunction indicates that the cause resides in . ., A.D. Conj. 235.9.

data.ref: Plu. QConv. 2.689b; τὸ ζητούμενον Aenesid. ap.

children.definition: one must investigate causes, Epicur. Ep. 1p.29U.
a giving the cause of a thing, Democr. 118, Aenesid. ap. S.E. P. 1.181, Phld. D. 1.10, A.D. Conj. 231.16; ἡ <περὶ> τῶν μετεώρων αἰ. Epicur. Ep. 2p.42U.
ready at giving the cause, inquiring into causes, αἰτιολογικώτατος, of Aristotle, D.L. 5.32; causal, τρόπος Epicur. Nat. 144 G.:— Subst., τὸ -κόν investigation of causes, Str. 2.3.8.
causal, σύνδεσμοι, σύνταξις, etc., A.D. Conj. 231.4, al., Adv. 200.2. Adv. -κῶς Id. Synt. 320.3.

definition: αἴτιος, α, ον, more rarely ος, ον Ar. Pl. 547: (v. αἰτία):—

children.definition: culpable, responsible, ἐπεὶ οὔ τί μοι αἴτιοί εἰσιν Il. 1.153, cf. B. 10.34, Hdt. 7.214: Comp. αἰτιώτερος Th. 4.20: Sup., τοὺς αἰτιωτάτους the most guilty, Hdt. 6.50; αἰ. τινος Id. 3.52.

data.quote: ἐπεὶ οὔ τί μοι αἴτιοί εἰσιν

children.definition: Subst., αἴτιος, ὁ, the accused, the culprit, A. Ch. 70, etc.; οἱ αἴ. τοῦ πατρός they who have sinned against my father, ib. 273:—c. gen. rei, οἱ αἴ. τοῦ φόνου ib. 117, cf. S. Ph. 590, Hdt. 4.200.

data.ref: A. Ch. 70, etc.; οἱ αἴ. τοῦ πατρός
273:—c. gen. rei, οἱ αἴ. τοῦ φόνου ib.

children.label: II
children.definition: responsible for, c. gen. rei, Hdt. 1.1, etc. ; αἴτιός τινός τινι being the cause of a thing to a person, Lys. 13.57, cf. D. 23.54, Isoc. 8.100: c. inf., αἴ. τὸν ἠέρα ξηρὸν εἶναι Hdt. 2.26; τοῦ μὴ φαλακροῦσθαι Id. 3.12, etc.; αἴ. θανεῖν S. Ant. 1173; αἰ. πεμφθῆναι ἄγγελον Antipho 5.23, cf. Lys. 13.82; αἴτιος τὸ σὲ ἀποκρίνασθαι Pl. La. 190e: Comp., τοῦ . . ἐλευθέραν εἶναι . . αἰτιώτερον D. 24.5, cf. 51.21: Sup. αἰτιώτατος, ἐν τῷ στενῷ ναυμαχῆσαι mainly instrumental in causing the sea-fight, Th. 1.74; αἰ. τοῦ μὴ ἀποθανεῖν D. 20.42; -ώτατόν τι καὶ τελέως δραστικόν Phld. D. 1.23.

data.ref: Hdt. 1.1, etc. ; αἴτιός τινός τινι being

children.definition: τό, cause, Hp. VM 6 (pl.), 21, Hdt. 7.125, E. IA 939, Th. 4.26, etc.; τί ποτʼ οὖν ἐστι τὸ αἴτιον τό . . μηδένα εἰπεῖν; D. 8.56; freq. in Philos., τὸ δʼ αἴ. τούτου εἶναι ὅτι . . Pl. Phd. 110e, etc.

data.ref: Th. 4.26, etc.; τί ποτʼ οὖν ἐστι τὸ αἴτιον τό . . μηδένα εἰπεῖν;

data.quote: τὸ δʼ αἴ. τούτου εἶναι ὅτι . .

children.definition: resembling a cause, quasi-causal, Stoic. 2.119 (in Adv. -δως, sed leg. -ῶδες); causal, οὐσία Plot. 6.8.14; στοιχεῖα Simp. in Ph. 17.25; τὸ αἰτιῶδες formal, as opp. to τὸ ὑλικόν, M.Ant. 4.21, etc.; πρότασις αἰ. giving the cause of the conclusion, Anon. in SE 3.36. Adv. -δως causally, Dam. Pr. 106.

children.label: II
children.definition: causal, ἀξίωμα Chrysipp.Stoic. 2.70; σύνδεσμοι A.D. Synt. 245.13, al.
PFay. 111 (iA.D.), Act.Ap. 25.7.
named from a fault, πάθος Sch. S. Aj. 205.
of or belonging to Etna ( Αἴτνη), Pi. P. 3.69, O. 6.96, A. Pr. 367, etc.; Sicilian, πῶλος S. OC 312; of a beetle, A. Fr. 233, Ar. Pax 73, S. Ichn. 300.

children.label: II
children.definition: ὁ, sea-fish, Opp. H. 1.512.

definition: αἰτρία, for αἰθρία, barbarism in Ar. Th. 1001.
ἀΐττεσθαι δικάζειν ἢ δικάζεσθαι, Hsch. (Fort. ἄττεσθαι· διάζειν ἢ διάζεσθαι.)

children.definition: president of Aetolian League, Phleg. Mir. 2.
Aetolia, Th. 3.96, etc.:—hence Αἰτωλοί, οἱ, Aetolians, Il. 2.638, etc.: fem. Αἰτωλίς, χώρη Hdt. 6.127: Adj. Αἰτωλικός, ή, όν, Th. 4.30, etc.
suddenly, E. IA 1581, Hp. Int. 39 ( αἰφνη-δίς, Hdn. Gr. 1.512; αἰφνη-δόν, Id. Epim. 270). (Prob. cognate with αἶψα rather than with ἄφαρ, ἄφνω).

data.ref: Id. Epim. 270). (Prob. cognate with αἶψα rather than with ἄφαρ, ἄφνω).

children.definition: unforeseen, sudden, A. Pr. 680, Th. 2.61, Arist. EN 1117a18; ἀφικνοῦνται αἰφνίδιοι τοῖς Χίοις Th. 8.14. Adv. -ίως Id. 2.53; also -ιον Plu. Num. 15.
profiting by strokes of good fortune, Vett.Val. 18.16.

definition: αἰχμάεις, αἰχμᾱτάς, Dor. for αἰχμήεις, αἰχμητής.

children.definition: throw the spear, αἰχμὰς αἰχμάσσουσι Il. 4.324; ἔνδον αἰχμάζειν play the warrior at home, A. Pers. 756; αἰχμάσαι τάδε to perform these feats of arms, S. Tr. 355; ‘trail a pike’, Men. Sam. 284.

children.label: II
children.definition: arm with the spear, πρὸς Ἀτρείδαισιν ᾔχμασας χέρα S. Aj. 97: metaph. of generalʼs speech, ἀ. τὴν διάνοιαν Onos. 1.13.

children.label: III
children.definition: wound, Nonn. D. 35.178 s.v.l.
captivity, D.S. 20.61, LXX Am. 1.15, al., Plu. Them. 31.

children.label: II
children.definition: body of captives, D.S. 17.70, LXX Nu. 31.12, al.

definition: αἰχμαλωτεύω, = sq., LXX Ge. 34.29, al., Ep.Eph. 4.8;

children.definition: capture, πλοῦτον Ps.-Callisth. 3.20.

take prisoner, D.S. 14.37, LXX 4 Ki. 24.14, al.:—more freq. in Med., αἰχμαλωτίζομαι J. BJ 4.8.1: fut. -ίσομαι ib. 2.4: aor. ᾐχμαλωτισάμην ib. 1.22.1, D.S. 13.24: pf. ᾐχμαλώτισμαι J. BJ 4.9.8 (with v.l. -σάμενοι); also in pass. sense, SIG 763 ( Cyzicus).
of or for a prisoner, E. Tr. 871.
captive, S. Aj. 1228, E. Tr. 28, LXX Ge. 31.26.
Adj. fem. of αἰχμάλωτος, τὰς αἰχμαλωτίδας χέρας S. Aj. 71.
Ar. Nu. 186.
captivator, Gloss.

taken by the spear, captive, prisoner, Pi. Fr. 223, Hdt. 6.79, 134; freq. of women, A. Ag. 1440, S. Tr. 417:— αἰχμάλωτοι prisoners of war, And. 4.22, Th. 3.70; αἰ. λαμβάνειν, ἄγειν take prisoner, X. Cyr. 3.1.37, 4.4.1; αἰ. γίγνεσθαι to be taken, ib. 3.1.7; of things, αἰ. χρήματα A. Eu. 400, cf. Ag. 334, D. 19.139; νῆες X. HG 2.3.8, IG 2.789; τὰ αἰ. booty, X. HG 4.1.26, An. 4.1.13; αἰχμάλωτον, τό, = ἀνδράποδον, D.S. 13.57.

children.label: II
children.definition: such as awaits a captive, Hdt. 9.76; εὐνά A. Th. 364 (lyr.); τύχη D.S. 27.6, Lib. Or. 59.157.

children.label: III
children.definition: ὁ, name of plasters, Aët. 15.20.
point of a spear, πάροιθε δὲ λάμπετο δουρὸς αἰ. χαλκείη Il. 6.320; αἰ. ἔγχεος 16.315.

data.quote: πάροιθε δὲ λάμπετο δουρὸς αἰ. χαλκείη

children.definition: point, of arrows, τοξουλκὸς αἰ. A. Pers. 239; ἀγκίστρου, κεράων, Opp. H. 1.216, C. 2.451.

children.label: II
children.definition: spear, Il. 12.45, etc.; δαμασίμβροτος αἰ. Pi. O. 9.79; πρὸς τὴν αἰχμὴν ἐτράπετο took to his spear, Hdt. 3.78; αἰχμῇ εἷλε with the spear, i.e. in war, Id. 5.94; otherwise rare in Prose, X. Cyr. 4.6.4.

data.ref: Pi. O. 9.79; πρὸς τὴν αἰχμὴν ἐτράπετο took to his

children.definition: body of spear-bearers, Pi. O. 7.19, E. Heracl. 276.
war, battle, κακῶς ἡ αἰ. ἑστήκεε the war went ill, Hdt. 7.152; παρμένοντας αἰχμᾷ standing their ground in battle, Pi. P. 8.40; θηρῶν with wild beasts, E. HF 158.

data.ref: Hdt. 7.152; παρμένοντας αἰχμᾷ standing their ground in

children.definition: sharpness, βρωτῆρας αἰ. A. Eu. 803.

children.label: III
children.definition: warlike spirit, αἰ. νέων θάλλει Terp. 6; θρέψε δʼ αἰχμὰν Ἀμφιτρύωνος Pi. N. 10.13; γυναικὸς αἰ. a womanʼs temper, A. Ag. 483 (lyr.), cf. Ch. 630 (lyr.; but perh. = rule, cf. Pr. 406). (Cf. Lith. jiešmas ‘spit’.)
armed with the spear, A. Pers. 137; pointed, σίδηρος Opp. C. 3.321.

definition: αἰχμητά [ᾰ], ὁ, Ep. collat. form of αἰχμητής, Il. 5.197.

children.definition: Opp. C. 3.211, Q.S. 8.85, Nonn. D. 28.122; as Adj., αἰ. γάμος prize of the spear, ib. 42.501.
warlike, Lyc. 454.

definition: αἰχμητής, οῦ, Dor. αἰχμ-ᾱτάς, ᾶ, ὁ, ( αἰχμή) poet.,

children.definition: spearman, warrior, esp. opp. to archers, Il. 2.543, Od. 2.19, al., Archil. 119, cj. in Alcm. 68, etc.

children.label: II
children.definition: Pi. as Adj.,
pointed (or spear-wielding), αἰ. κεραυνός P. 1.5.
warlike, αἰ. θυμός N. 9.37:—fem. αἴχμητις (sic), EM 595.39.
bound in war, = αἰχμάλωτος, S. Fr. 47 (fort. -όλετος, cf. EM 41.3).
spearman, Hdt. 1.103, 215.

definition: αἶψα ( Boeot. ἦψα prob. in Corinn. BKT 5(2).36), Adv.

children.definition: quick, forthwith, on a sudden, freq. in Hom. (also αἶψα μάλα, αἶψα δʼ ἔπειτα, Il. 4.70, Od. 15.193), cf. Sapph. 1.13, Thgn. 663, Sol. 2, Pi. P. 4.133, Emp. 35.14, A. Supp. 481.—Poet., exc. in Mon.Ant. 18.322 ( Gortyn).
swift-speeding, epith. of Boreas, Hes. Th. 379, Poet. ap. Apollod. 3.4.4.

quick, speedy, sudden, αἰψηρὸς δὲ κόρος κρυεροῖο γόοιο satiety in grief comes soon, Od. 4.103; λῦσεν δʼ ἀγορὴν αἰψηρήν he dismissed the assembly in haste, Il. 19.276, Od. 2.257; Ζεφύρου αἰ. πνοαί Pi. Parth. 2.17; πούς Lyc. 515. Adv. -ῶς Aristarch. ap. Apollon. Lex. s.v. αἶψα.—Not in Trag.

data.ref: Od. 4.103; λῦσεν δʼ ἀγορὴν αἰψηρήν he dismissed the assembly

definition: ἀΐω (A), Ep. and Lyr. word, freq. used by Trag. in lyr., cf. Hermipp. 47.7 (anap.); once only in dialogue ( S. OC 304): only pres. and impf. ( aor. ἐπ-ήϊσα Hdt. 9.93):—

children.definition: perceive by the ear, hear, c. acc. rei, οὐκ ἀΐεις ἅ τέ φησι; Il. 15.130, cf. 248; Νέστωρ δὲ πρῶτος κτύπον ἄϊε 10.532, cf. 21.388, Pi. Pae. 6.8, A. Ag. 55, Supp. 59, E. Med. 148, etc.: c. gen.rei, Sapph. 1.6, S. OC 304, Ph. 1410: c. gen. pers., ἀΐει μου . . βασιλεύς A. Pers. 633;—also, perceive by the eye, see, Od. 18.11, S. OC 181:—generally, perceive, οὐκ ἀΐεις ὡς Τρῶες . . ἥαται ἄγχι νεῶν; Il. 10.160.

data.quote: οὐκ ἀΐεις ὡς Τρῶες . . ἥαται ἄγχι νεῶν;

children.definition: listen to, give ear to, δίκης Hes. Op. 213 (dub. l.); obey, A. Pers. 874, Ar. Nu. 1166. (Cf. Skt. āvis ‘clear’, Lat. au-dio.) [ Hom. uses ᾰ always in pres., ᾰῐω; so A. Pers. 633, S. Ph. 1410; but ᾱῐεις, ᾱῐων A. Supp. 59 (prob.), S. OC 181, 304: impf. ᾱῐε Il. 10.532, 21.388 (as always in Trag.), but ᾰῐεν Il. 11.463, ᾰῐον 18.222:— ι is always short, except ᾰῑε in Hes. Op. 213 (dub. l.), and perh. ἀϊόντεσσι Od. 1.352.]
breathe, (dub.) once in impf., ἐπεὶ φίλον ἄϊον ἦτορ when I was breathing out my life, Il. 15.252.

definition: αἰών, ῶνος, ὁ, Ion. and Ep. also ἡ, as in Pi. P. 4.186, E. Ph. 1484: apocop. acc. αἰῶ, like Ποσειδῶ, restored by Ahrens (from AB 363) in A. Ch. 350: (properly αἰϝών, cf. aevum, v. αἰεί):—

children.definition: period of existence ( τὸ τέλος τὸ περιέχον τὸν τῆς ἑκάστου ζωῆς χρόνον . . αἰὼν ἑκάστου κέκληται Arist. Cael. 279a25):

data.quote: τὸ τέλος τὸ περιέχον τὸν τῆς ἑκάστου ζωῆς χρόνον . . αἰὼν ἑκάστου κέκληται

children.label: I
children.definition: lifetime, life, ψυχή τε καὶ αἰών Il. 16.453; ἐκ δʼ αἰ. πέφαται Il. 19.27; μηδέ τοι αἰ. φθινέτω Od. 5.160; λείπει τινά Il. 5.685; ἀπʼ αἰῶνος νέος ὤλεο ( Zenod. νέον) 24.725; τελευτᾶν τὸν αἰῶνα Hdt. 1.32, etc.; αἰῶνος στερεῖν τινά A. Pr. 862; αἰῶνα διοιχνεῖν Id. Eu. 315; συνδιατρίβειν Cratin. 1; αἰ. Αἰακιδᾶν, periphr. for the Aeacidae, S. Aj. 645 s. v. l.; ἀπέπνευσεν αἰῶνα E. Fr. 801; ἐμὸν κατʼ αἰῶνα A. Th. 219.
age, generation, αἰ. ἐς τρίτον ib. 744; ὁ μέλλων αἰών posterity, D. 18.199, cf. Pl. Ax. 370c.
oneʼs life, destiny, lot, S. Tr. 34, E. Andr. 1215, Fr. 30, etc.

children.label: II
children.definition: long space of time, age, αἰὼν γίγνεται ʼtis an age, Men. 536.5; esp. with Preps., ἀπʼ αἰῶνος of old, Hes. Th. 609, Ev.Luc. 1.70; οἱ ἀπὸ τοῦ αἰ. Ῥωμαῖοι D.C. 63.20; διʼ αἰῶνος perpetually, A. Ch. 26, Eu. 563; all oneʼs life long, S. El. 1024; διʼ αἰῶνος μακροῦ, ἀπαύστου, A. Supp. 582, 574; τὸν διʼ αἰ. χρόνον for ever, Id. Ag. 554; εἰς ἅπαντα τὸν αἰ. Lycurg. 106, Isoc. 10.62; εἰς τὸν αἰ. LXX Ge. 3.23, al., D.S. 21.17, Ev.Jo. 8.35, Ps.-Luc. Philopatr. 17; εἰς αἰῶνα αἰῶνος LXX Ps. 131(132).14; ἐξ αἰῶνος καὶ ἕως αἰῶνος ib. Je. 7.7; ἐπʼ αἰ. ib. Ex. 15.18; ἕως αἰῶνος ib. 1 Ki. 1.22, al.:— without a Prep., τὸν ἅπαντα αἰ. Arist. Cael. 279a22; τὸν αἰῶνα Lycurg. 62, Epicur. Ep. 1p.8U.; eternity, opp. χρόνος, Pl. Ti. 37d, cf. Metrod. Fr. 37, Ph. 1.496, 619, Plot. 3.7.5, etc.; τοὺς ὑπὲρ τοῦ αἰῶνος φόβους Epicur. Sent. 20.

data.ref: Men. 536.5; esp. with Preps., ἀπʼ αἰῶνος
S. El. 1024; διʼ αἰῶνος μακροῦ, ἀπαύστου,
Id. Ag. 554; εἰς ἅπαντα τὸν αἰ.
1 Ki. 1.22, al.:— without a Prep., τὸν ἅπαντα αἰ.

children.definition: space of time clearly defined and marked out, epoch, age, ὁ αἰὼν οὗτος this present world, opp. ὁ μέλλων, Ev.Matt. 13.22, cf. Ep.Rom. 12.2; ὁ νῦν αἰ. 1 Ep.Tim. 6.17, 2 Ep.Tim. 4.10:—hence in pl., the ages, i.e. eternity, Phld. D. 3 Fr. 84; εἰς πάντας τοὺς αἰ. LXX To. 13.4; εἰς τοὺς αἰ. ib. Si. 45.24, al., Ep.Rom. 1.25, etc.; εἰς τοὺς αἰ. τῶν αἰώνων LXX 4 Ma. 18.24, Ep.Phil. 4.20, etc.; ἀπὸ τῶν αἰ., πρὸ τῶν αἰ., Ep.Eph. 3.9, 1 Cor. 2.7; τὰ τέλη τῶν αἰ. ib. 10.11.

data.ref: Ep.Phil. 4.20, etc.; ἀπὸ τῶν αἰ., πρὸ τῶν αἰ.,
1 Cor. 2.7; τὰ τέλη τῶν αἰ. ib. 10.11.

children.definition: ὁ, personified, Αἰὼν Χρόνου παῖς E. Heracl. 900 (lyr.), cf. Corp.Herm. 11, etc.; as title of various divine beings, Dam. Pr. 151, al.; esp.=Persian Zervan, Suid. s.v. Ἡρασκος.
Pythag., = 10, Theol.Ar. 59.

children.label: B
children.definition: spinal marrow (perh. regarded as seat of life), h.Merc. 42, 119, Pi. Fr. 111, Hp. Epid. 7.122; perh. also Il. 19.27.
to be eternal, Phot., Suid.; to be eternalized, Dam. Pr. 105.

definition: αἰώνιος, ον, also α, ον Pl. Ti. 37d, Ep.Hebr. 9.12:—

children.definition: lasting for an age (αἰών II), perpetual, eternal (but dist. fr. ἀΐδιος, Plot. 3.7.3), μέθη Pl. R. 363d; ἀνώλεθρον . . ἀλλʼ οὐκ αἰώνιον Id. Lg. 904a, cf. Epicur. Sent. 28; αἰ. κατὰ ψυχὴν ὄχλησις Id. Nat. 131 G.; κακά, δεινά, Phld. Herc. 1251.18, D. 1.13; αἰ. ἀμοιβαῖς βασανισθησόμενοι ib. 19; τοῦ αἰ. θεοῦ Ep.Rom. 16.26, Ti.Locr. 96c; οὐ χρονίη μοῦνον . . ἀλλʼ αἰωνίη Aret. CA 1.5; αἰ. διαθήκη, νόμιμον, πρόσταγμα, LXX Ge. 9.16, Ex. 27.21, To. 1.6; ζωή Ev.Matt. 25.46, Porph. Abst. 4.20; κόλασις Ev.Matt. l.c., Olymp. in Grg. p.278J.; πρὸ χρόνων αἰ. 2 Ep.Tim. 1.9: opp. πρόσκαιρος, 2 Ep.Cor. 4.18.
holding an office or title for life, perpetual, γυμνασίαρχος CPHerm. 62.
= Lat. saecularis, Phleg. Macr. 4.
Adv. -ίως eternally, νοῦς ἀκίνητος αἰ. πάντα ὤν Procl. Inst. 172, cf. Simp. in Epict. p.77D.; perpetually, μισεῖν Sch. E. Alc. 338.
τό, = ἀείζωον τὸ μέγα, Ps.- Dsc. 4.88.
perpetuitas, Gloss.
perpetual memorial, Ostr. 1148.
immortal, title of Egyptian kings, Πτολεμαῖος OGI 90.4 ( Rosetta, ii B. C.), PMag.Par. 1.154; of God, PMag.Lond. 46.176,482.
eternal ruler of the heavens, PMag.Berol. 1.201.
seeing with eternal eyes, PMag.Lond. 46.465.
swing, hammock, chariot on springs, Pl. Lg. 789d.
noose, halter, S. OT 1264 (in the form ἐώρα).

passive exercise, Plu. An seni 2.793b, Antyll. ap. Orib. 6.23, Sor. 1.125: pl., IG 4.955 ( Epid., ii A. D.).

children.label: III
children.definition: fluctuation of mind, Metrod. Herc. 831.8 (cf. Epicur. Fr. 434).

definition: αἰωρέω fut. Pass. -ηθήσομαι D.C. 41.1, ( ἀπ-) Hp. Fract. 14, but -ήσομαι Aristid. 2.289J.: aor. ᾐωρήθην (v. infr.): pf. ᾐώρημαι Opp. H. 3.532: ( ἀείρω):—

children.definition: lift up, raise, ὑγρὸν νῶτον αἰωρεῖ, of the eagle raising his back and feathers, Pi. P. 1.9; swing as in a hammock, αἰ. [γυναῖκα] ἐπὶ κλίνης φερομένην Hp. Mul. 1.68, cf. Aret. CA 1.4; τοὺς ὄφεις . . ὑπὲρ τῆς κεφαλῆς αἰωρῶν D. 18.260.

data.quote: τοὺς ὄφεις . . ὑπὲρ τῆς κεφαλῆς αἰωρῶν

children.label: II
children.definition: Pass., to be hung, hang, δέρματα περὶ τοὺς ὤμους αἰωρεύμενα Hdt. 7.92; αἰωρουμένων τῶν ὀστῶν being raised, lifted, Pl. Phd. 98d; αἷμα ᾐωρεῖτο spouted up, Bion 1.25; ὁ ἥλιος ὑπὸ πνευμάτων αἰωρεῖται is tossed, carried to and fro, Diog.Oen. Fr. 8.

data.ref: Bion 1.25; ὁ ἥλιος ὑπὸ πνευμάτων αἰωρεῖται

children.definition: swing, float in air, Pl. La. 184a; hover, of birds, Arist. Mir. 836a12; of a dream, S. El. 1390 (lyr.); oscillate, Pl. Phd. 112b; of an army, αἰωρουμένης στρατιᾶς περὶ Μεσοποταμίαν Plu. Ant. 28.

children.label: b
children.definition: take passive exercise, Gal. Thras. 23.

to be in suspense, ἐν κινδύνῳ to hang in doubt and danger, Th. 7.77; αἰ. ἐν ἄλλοις depend upon . ., Pl. Mx. 248a; αἰωρηθεὶς ὑπὲρ μεγάλων playing for a high stake, Hdt. 8.100; αἰ. τὴν ψυχήν X. Cyn. 4.4; τὸ μὴ -ούμενον τῆς ψυχῆς Epicur. Nat. 22G.
Pass., to be held in suspense, threatened, ἀπαιδίας πρὸς τιμωρίαν -ουμένης Chor. p.71.3B [26:2:71].
that which is hung up or hovers, Lyc. 1080.
hanging cord, halter, E. Hel. 353 (lyr.); hanging slings or chains, Id. Or. 984 (lyr.).
oscillatory movement, esp. Medic., of passive exercise, Pl. Ti. 89a, cf. Gal. 10.710; αἰ. διʼ ὀχημάτων Poll. 10.51.
one must take passive exercise, Sor. 1.109; ἐν φορείῳ Herod.Med. ap. Aët. 9.13.
hanging, AP 5.203 ( Mel.).
softly, gently, Pi. P. 4.156; cf. ἦκα.

definition: Ἀκαδήμεια (the form is protected by metre in Alex. 25, 94, cf. Ar. Nu. 1005, Epicr. 11.11, St. Byz. s.v. Ἑκαδήμεια, Ath. 10.419d), freq. written Ἀκαδημία, ἡ,

children.definition: Academy, a gymnasium in the suburbs of Athens, named from the hero Academus, ἐν δρόμοισιν Ἀκαδήμου θεοῦ Eup. 32, cf. Pl. Ly. 203a, etc., where Plato taught: hence, the Platonic school of philosophy, Ἀκ. παλαιά, μέση, νεωτέρα Phld. Acad.Ind. p.77 M.: prov., Ἀκαδημίηθεν ἥκεις, of a philosopher, Apostol. 2.1:—hence Adj. Ἀκαδημεικός, ή, όν, Academic, of the school of Plato, Phld. Acad.Ind. p.18 M.: also Ἀκαδημαϊκός, Plu. Comm.not. 2.1077c, Ath. 11.509a, Luc. Pisc. 43, Timo 35 codd., etc.; Ἀκαδημιακός, D.L. 4.67, etc.; Ἀκαδημικός, Cic. Att. 13.12.3 and 16.1; Ἀκαδήμιος, Philostr. VA 7.2 s.v.l.

data.ref: Pl. Ly. 203a, etc., where Plato taught: hence,

children.definition: not to be put down, Ph. 1.39, al.; not weakened, Sor. 1.21.
uncleanness, foulness, of a wound or sore, Hp. Fract. 31, cf. Pl. Ti. 72c (pl.); ἀγγείων Hp. Epid. 6.31.

depravity, D. 21.119.
ceremonial impurity, LXX Le. 15.3, al.

uncleansed, foul, ἀήρ Hp. Aër. 6; of the body, Arist. Pr. 883b27; ἕλκος Hp. Fract. 27; of a woman, quae menstrua non habet [not menstruating], Demad. Fr. 4, Luc. Lex. 19; of ceremonial impurity, LXX Le. 12.2, al., IG 3.74.3.

not purged away, unpurged, S. OT 256, Pl. Lg. 854b.

ungovernable, Ps.-Phoc. 193, Plu. Nic. 8. Adv. -τως, λυττᾶν Ph. 2.48; μαργαίνειν Sch. Opp. H. 1.38.

unsurpassed, Ptol. Tetr. 157.
lacking nothing, βίος Vett.Val. 67.18, cf. Ps.-Callisth. 2.11. Adv. -τως without delay, BGU 1126.11 (i B. C.).
spike, prick, goad, A.R. 3.1323, AP 6.41 ( Agath.).

talk nonsense, Astramps. Orac. 74.9.
unfitness of times, opp. ἐπικαιρία, Democr. 26e (pl.); opp. εὐκαιρία, Pl. Phdr. 272a; opp. ἐγκαιρία, Id. Plt. 305d; time of trouble, Lib. Or. 59.38.
unseasonableness, ἐνιαυτῶν πολλῶν ἀ. Pl. Lg. 709a (pl.); τῶν πνευμάτων Arist. Pr. 941b25 (pl.).
impropriety, Pl. Smp. 182a.
bad taste in writing, D.H. Dem. 7, al.

guilelessness, D. 59.81, Arist. Rh. 1389b9, LXX Jb. 2.3, etc.

guileless, Phot.; Medic., benign, μυρμηκιά Heliod. ap. Orib. 45.14.44. Adv. -θως Iambl. Protr. 21.ιθʹ.

backbone or spine of fish, A. Fr. 275, Ar. V. 969, Alex. 110.11, al.; of serpents, Hdt. 2.75, Theoc. 24.32, A.R. 4.150; of men, Hdt. 4.72, Hp. Art. 14, E. El. 492, Arist. PA 654a26, Gal. 2.451, etc.; improperly used of mammalia, acc. to Arist. APo. 98a22; of the spinous processes of the vertebrae, Gal. 2.758; χονδρώδεις ἄ. false ribs, Ruf. Oss. 25.

spinous, τὰ -κά Thphr. HP 6.1.3, al.; φύσις ib. 4.6.
of thorns, στέφανος Ev.Marc. 15.17, Jo. 19.5.
thorny, ἐν ἀ. ἀταρποῖς Anacreont. 53.12.

prickly, χαίτη (of the plant ἔχις) Nic. Th. 542; ῥόδον Id. Fr. 74.9.

Am. 4; so a poem is called Καλλιόπης ἄ. θύος AP 6.321 ( Leon.): —ἄκαπνα γὰρ αἰὲν ἀοιδοὶ θύομεν we sacrifice without a fire of our own, i.e. live at others’ expense, Call. Fr. 53P.

headless, APl. 16.116 ( Euod.), Epigr.Gr. 1013 ( Memnon).

Asin. 37, Plot. 5.5.7; also ἀκαρῆ διαλιπών (sc. χρόνον) having waited a moment, Ar. Nu. 496; ἀκαρὲς ὥρας in a moment, Plu. Ant. 28; ἡμέρας μιᾶς ἀ. Id. Fac.lun. 2.938a; ἐπʼ ἀκαρές Aret. SD 2.2.

ἀκάρναξ· Hsch.), Ath. 8.356b.

Epict. 2.23.46:—hence ἀκαταληψία, ἡ, inability to comprehend or attain conviction, Sceptic term, attrib. to Stoics by Galen, Stoic. 1.17, but to Arcesilaus by Cic. Att. 13.19.3, Numen. ap. Eus. PE 14.7, S.E. P. 1.1.

unburnt, Hp. Haem. 2, X. An. 3.5.13.
incombustible, Arist. Mete. 387a18, Thphr. Lap. 4; unquenchable (v.l. for ἄσβεστος) , πῦρ LXX Jb. 20.26.
make fireproof, Zos.Alch. p.166B.
not branded, of horses, Str. 5.1.9.

definition: ἀκάχημαι, ἀκαχήσω, ἀκάχησα, etc., v. ἀχέω.

children.definition: trouble, grieve, τινά Od. 16.432:— Med., μὴ . . λίην ἀκαχίζεο θυμῷ be not troubled, Il. 6.486: c. part., μή τι θανὼν ἀκαχίζευ Od. 11.486.

definition: ἀκαχμένος, η, ον, Epic part. (cf. ἀκή A),

children.definition: sharp-edged, ἀ. ὀξέϊ χαλκῷ Il. 15.482, Od. 1.99, al.; πέλεκυν . . ἀμφοτέρωθεν ἀ. 5.235; φάσγανον 22.80.

children.label: II
children.definition: armed, c. dat., γένος σκυλάκων κυνόδουσιν ἀ. Opp. C. 1.476, cf. 3.252.
inf. -έμεν Antim. 80.

definition: ἀκέανος, ὁ, kind of leguminous vegetable, Pherecr. 188, cf. Ael.Dion. Fr. 28.

children.definition: Hsch.
Pi. P. 3.14, I. 1.7, Philostr. Ep. 16; of Asclepius, IG 3.171; of Avars, APl. 16.72.
pathless, Hsch.

definition: ἀκέλευμνον οὐ βεβηκὼς ἀσφαλῶς, οἱ δὲ τὸν σκληρὸν σίδηρον, Hsch.

children.definition: unbidden, A. Ag. 731 (lyr.), S. Aj. 1284, E. El. 71, Pl. Lg. 953d. Adv. -ως Suid. s.v. ἀπαγγέλτως.
without husk or capsule, of fruits, Thphr. CP 1.17.8.
without vain conceit, M.Ant. 1.16. Adv. -ως Sch. Od. 3.411:—hence ἀκενο-δοξία, ἡ, Zonar.
shunning vain pursuits, Antip.Tars. Stoic. 3.254, Cic. Fam. 15.17.4, M.Ant. 1.6.
needing no spur, Pi. O. 1.21, AP 5.202 ( Asclep.), Ael. NA 15.24.
unpricked, by love, Chor. Zach. 5.

children.label: II
children.definition: flawless, of crystals, Plin. HN 37.28.

definition: ἀκέντριστος, ον, = foreg. [ἀκέντητος] I, Hsch., EM 432.11.

children.definition: stingless, κηφῆνες Pl. R. 552c, 564b; without spur, of a cock, Clyt. 1; without thorns, βάτος Ph. 2.91.
not responding to the spur, of horses, Hippiatr. 105: metaph., of style, pointless, Longin. 21.2.

children.label: II
children.definition: not occupying a cardinal point, Man. 5.108, Vett.Val. 89.30.
absence from a cardinal point, Demoph. ap. Jul.Laod. in Cat.Cod.Astr. 5(1).189 (pl.).

definition: ἀκέομαι [ᾰ], Ion. imper. ἀκέο (for ἀκέεο) Hdt. 3.40; Ep. part. ἀκειόμενος Il. 16.29, Od. 14.383, Pi. P. 9.104: fut. ἀκέσομαι D.C. 38.19, Ep. ἀκέσσομαι Musae. 199, Att. ἀκοῦμαι (ἐξ-) Men. 863: aor. ἠκεσάμην, Ep. imper. ἄκεσσαι, etc.:— Pass., v. sub fin.:

children.label: I
children.definition: heal, cure, c. acc. of thing healed, ἕλκος ἄκεσσαι Il. 16.523; ἕλκεʼ ἀκειόμενοι 16.29; ψώρην ἀκέσασθαι Hdt. 4.90; of part healed, τὰ ἔσω ἀσκοῖσιν Hp. Mochl. 25; ἄχος S. Tr. 1035; βλέφαρον ἀκέσαιο τυφλόν E. Hec. 1067; τὸν Λητώ τε καὶ Ἄρτεμις . . ἀκέοντο Il. 5.448, cf. 402: c. gen. morbi, νούσου . . μʼ ἀκέσω βαρυαλγέος Epigr.Gr. 803 ( Delos), cf. Paus. 8.18.8.

data.quote: τὸν Λητώ τε καὶ Ἄρτεμις . . ἀκέοντο

children.definition: stanch, quench, πίον τʼ ἀκέοντό τε δίψαν Il. 22.2, cf. Pi. P. 9.104.
mend, repair, νῆας ἀκειόμενος Od. 14.383; freq. of tailors or cobblers, Luc. Fug. 33, Nec. 17; of a spider mending its web, Arist. HA 623a18.
make amends for, repair, ἁμαρτάδα Hdt. 1.167; τὰ ἐπιφερόμενα Id. 3.16, cf. E. Med. 199; μήνιμα Antipho 4.3.7; ἀδίκημα Pl. R. 364c; ἀπορίας X. Mem. 2.7.1.

children.label: II
children.definition: apply a remedy, make amends, ἀλλʼ ἀκεώμεθα θᾶσσον· ἀκεσταί τοι φρένες ἐσθλῶν Il. 13.115; ἀλλʼ ἀκέσασθε, φίλοι Od. 10.69, cf. S. Ant. 1027, Hdt. 3.40, Pl. Phlb. 30b.

data.quote: ἀλλʼ ἀκεώμεθα θᾶσσον· ἀκεσταί τοι φρένες ἐσθλῶν

children.label: III
children.definition: Act., Hp. Loc.Hom. 10; ἀκέεται in pass. sense, Aret. CA 1.1; ἀκεομένου τοῦ κακοῦ Id. SD 1.6: aor. ἀκεσθῆναι Paus. 2.27.3.

data.ref: Hp. Loc.Hom. 10; ἀκέεται in pass. sense,

children.definition: noiselessly, Hsch. ἄκερα· ἔνδυμά τι πολυτελές, Id.
to be ἀκέραιος, Eust. 277.16.

definition: ἀκέραιος, ον (fem. -αία Sch. Ar. Pl. 593), Prose word (used by E., v. infr.) for poet. ἀκήρατος,

children.definition: pure, unmixed, ὕδωρ Arist. HA 605a15; οἶνος Dsc. 5.6; ἀργύριον Poll. 3.86, etc.; untouched, γῆ, νομή, Pl. Criti. 111b, Arist. HA 575b3; unalloyed, ἡδοναί Epicur. Sent. 12.
pure in blood, E. Ph. 943.

children.label: II
children.definition: unharmed, unravaged, ἀ. ἀπολαμβάνειν τὴν πόλιν Hdt. 3.146; γῆ Th. 2.18; χώρα D. 1.28; δύναμις, of an army, in full force, Th. 3.3; of troops, fresh, X. An. 6.5.9, Plb. 1.40.12, etc.; of property, untouched, οὐσία D. 44.23; ἐᾶν τι ἀσινὲς καὶ ἀ. IG 3.1418f; of a person, Pers. Stoic. 1.99.
pure, inviolate, ἀκέραιον ὡς σῴσαιμι Μενέλεῳ λέχος E. Hel. 48; [τέχνη] ἀβλαβὴς καὶ ἀ. Pl. R. 342b; complete, perfect, φαντασίαι Phld. D. 3.8; ἐλπίς Plb. 6.9.3; ὁρμαί Id. 1.45.2.
uncontaminated, guileless, E. Or. 922; incorruptible, κριτής D.H. 7.4: c. gen., ἀ. κακῶν ἠθῶν Pl. R. 409a, cf. Men. Epit. 489; unprejudiced, with an open mind, Plb. 21.31.12.

anew, Id. 23.4.10; while matters are undecided, Id. 6.24.9; ἀκέραιον ἐᾶν leave alone, Id. 2.2.10; εἰς -ον ἀποκαθιστάναι, = Lat. in integrum restituere, IG 14.951. Adv. -ως, of payment, in full, Cic. Att. 15.21.2; unreservedly, Phld. Lib. p.57O.
guilelessness, innocence, Suid.
freshness, of troops, Plb. 3.73.6, 6.40.9.
integrity, Just. Edict. 7.8 Intr.
unmixed, pure, τόλμης ἀνδρείας Pl. Plt. 310d. Adv. ἀκεράστως, πνέων, gloss on ἀκραής, Sch. Od. 2.421.

children.label: II
children.definition: not coalescing, D.H. Comp. 22.
without horns, Pl. Plt. 265c sq., Arist. HA 501a14, al.

definition: ἀκέραυνος, ον, = sq., of Capaneus, A. Fr. 17.

children.definition: not struck by lightning, Luc. J.Tr. 25.
want of gain, loss, Pi. O. 1.53:—also -ία Procop. Arc. 13.
bringing no gain, unprofitable, χάρις S. OC 1484, cf. Pl. Cra. 417d, D.H. 6.9, AP 9.649 ( Maced.). Adv. -δῶς without profit, Arist. Pol. 1309a13, Plu. Aud.poet. 2.27d.

children.label: II
children.definition: not greedy of gain, φιλοτιμία Id. Arist. 1. Adv. -ῶς Id. Frat. 2.483e.
unwoven, AP 7.472 ( Leon).
tailless, Arist. PA 689b6.
want of money, Ar. Fr. 15 (unless as Verb -ιᾶν).
Arist. HA 499b16.

definition: ἀκερσεκόμης (ἀκερσι- in Nonn. ll. cc. infr.), ου, ὁ, ( Dor. voc. -κόμα Pi. Pae. 9.45: dat. pl. -κόμοισιν Nonn. D. 14.232), ( κείρω, κόμη)

children.definition: with unshorn hair, i.e. ever-young (for Greek youths wore long hair till they reached manhood), of Phoebus, Il. 20.39, h.Ap. 134, etc.
long-haired, Nonn. D. 10.29, al.; cf. ἀκειρεκόμης.

definition: ἀκερσίλα μυρσίνη ( Sicel), Hsch. ἀκερχές· ἀπενθές, Id.

children.definition: without hoarseness, Aret. CA 1.10.

children.label: II
children.definition: Act., curing hoarseness, Id. CD 1.8.
Pl. Plt. 265b, Ael. NA 2.53, (Max.Tyr. 17.5.
Suid. s.v. ἀκεραιοσύνη.
not horned, AP 6.258 ( Adaeus).
healing mortals, of Asclepius, Orph. L. 8; ἀ. ἄνθος Poet. de herb. 146.
wholesome, healing, Plu. Aq. 2.956f.
healing, epith. of Apollo, Paus. 6.24.6.
healing, cure, Hdt. 4.90, 109, Hierocl. in CA 25p.477M.; τὸν εὑράμενον παυσινόσους ἀκέσεις IG 3.900.
mending, repair, θυρᾶν IG 4.1484 (Epid.); μηχανώματος GDI 2502.62 (Delph.).

children.label: II
children.definition: plaster, Asclep. ap. Gal. 13.442.
curable, Hsch.
Call. Fr.anon. 227.
healing disease, cj. in AP 9.516 ( Crin.).
assuaging pain or toil, Nonn. D. 7.86.
healer: Adj., ἀ. χαλινός rein that tames the steed, S. OC 714 (lyr.).
tailorʼs shop, Lib. Or. 11.254.
medicinal, healing, metaph., κακῶν φάρμακον App. Pun. 88.
Lyc. 1052: Phrygian acc. to Sch.Ven. Il. 22.2, Eust. 1254.2, EM 51.7.
menders of torn clothes, X. Cyr. 1.6.16 (v.l. ἠπηταί), cf. Alciphr. 3.27.
bars in sublimating furnaces, Dsc. 5.74.
fitted for healing or mending: ἡ -κή (sc. τέχνη) Democr. 154, Pl. Plt. 281b, Ael. NA 6.57, Gal. Thras. 30.
the healing art, A.R. 2.512, APl. 16.272 ( Leont.), Max. 314.

definition: ἀκεστορίς, ίδος, ἡ, fem. of ἀκέστωρ, Hp. Flat. 1.

children.definition: curable, Hp. Art. 58; πρᾶγμα Antipho 5.91: metaph., ἀκεσταὶ φρένες ἐσθλῶν the hearts of the noble admit treatment, Il. 13.115.
darning-needle, Luc. DMort. 14[4].1, PLips. 28.6.
sempstress, Antip.Tars. Stoic. 3.254, Luc. Rh.Pr. 24; ἀ., ἡ, title of play by Antiphanes: in pl., title of mime by Sophron.

definition: ἀκεστρίς, ίδος, ἡ, fem. of ἀκεστήρ,

children.definition: midwife, Hp. Carn. 19.
remedy, S. Ichn. 317, Fr. 480.
healer, saviour, Φοῖβος E. Andr. 900.
healing, salvation, AP 9.349 ( Leon.), Max. 167.
bringing cure, healing, c. gen. rei, E. Ion 1005, Astyd.Trag. 6.
allaying pain, Paetus ap. Hp. Ep. 2, AP 9.815, IG 14.1015, Men.Rh.p.443 S.

definition: ἀκεύει τηρεῖ ( Cypr.), Hsch., dub. in Leg.Gort. 2.17.

children.definition: headless: οἱ ἀ., fabulous creatures in Libya, Hdt. 4.191; ἀ. ταῦροι J. BJ 4.8.4.

without beginning, λόγος, μῦθος, Pl. Phdr. 264c, Lg. 752a; without peroration, μῦθος Luc. Scyth. 9; of verses which lack the first mora, Heph. 6.2, al., cf. Ath. 14.632d. Adv. -λως, ἐμβάλλειν τοῖς πράγμασι Hermog. Inv. 2.7.
with no known head, Suid.; ἀ., οἱ, Just. Nov. 109 Praef.

children.label: II
children.definition: Artem. 1.35; cf. Lat. capite deminutus.
to be silent (cf. sq.), only opt. pres. ἀκέοις A.R. 1.765.
softly, silently, fem. ἀκέουσα Il. 1.565, Od. 11.142: dual. ἀκέοντε 14.195; also indecl., ἀκέων δαίνυσθε 21.89, cf. h.Ap. 404; Ἀθηναίη ἀκέων ἦν Il. 4.22, 8.459.
point, Hsch., Suid.
silence, ἀκὴν ἔχεν Mosch. 2.18; ἀκὴν ἦγες Hsch.
healing, Hp. Mochl. 21, cf. Hum. 1.
carelessness, indifference, in pl., Emp. 136, A.R. 2.219: sg., 3.260, Diog.Oen. 24.

children.label: II
children.definition: anguish, A.R. 3.298 (Sch. πολυκηδείαισι).
uncared for, Il. 6.60; esp. unburied, AP 7.686 ( Pall.); unkempt, κάρηνον Nonn. D. 10.272. Adv. -τως without care for others, ruthlessly, Il. 22.465, 24.417, cf. AP 9.375.
unburied, Plu. Per. 28, J. AJ 6.14.8.

definition: ἀκηδέω, fut. -ήσω cj. in S. Ant. 414, cf. Q.S. 10.29: aor. -ησα 12.376, ἀκήδεσα Il. 14.427: ( ἀκηδής):—

children.definition: take no care for, no heed of, c. gen., οὔ τίς εὑ ἀκήδεσεν Il. l.c.; οὐ μέν μευ ζώοντος ἀκήδεις, ἀλλὰ θανόντος 23.70; σαυτοῦ δʼ ἀκήδει δυστυχοῦντος (imper.) A. Pr. 508, cf. Mosch. 4.81, Onos. 33.3.

data.quote: οὐ μέν μευ ζώοντος ἀκήδεις, ἀλλὰ θανόντος

children.definition: grow weary, Q.S. 10.16. (See also ἀφειδέω.)

children.label: I
children.definition: Pass., uncared for: esp. unburied, ὄφρα μὲν Ἕκτωρ κεῖται ἀ. Il. 24.554; ἢ αὔτως κεῖται ἀ. Od. 20.130; σώμοτʼ ἀκηδέα κεῖται Od. 24.187, cf. 6.26, 19.18. Adv. -ῶς Suid.

children.label: II
children.definition: Act., without care or sorrow, Il. 24.526, Hes. Th. 489, AP 11.42 ( Crin.).
careless, heedless, τὸν δὲ γυναῖκες ἀκηδέες οὐ κομέουσιν Od. 17.319, cf. Il. 21.123: c.gen., taking no thought for, φίλων S. Fr. 208.10; παίδων Pl. Lg. 913c.

data.quote: τὸν δὲ γυναῖκες ἀκηδέες οὐ κομέουσιν

children.label: III
children.definition: harm harmless, Opp. H. 1.611, 2.648, cf. Epic. ap. Suid.
indifference, torpor, apathy, Hp. Gland. 12, Cic. Att. 12.45.
weariness, exhaustion, Luc. Herm. 77, D.C. Fr. 73; πνεύματος LXX Is. 61.3.
neglect, disregard, τῆς παραφορῆς Aret. CA 1.1.
Hsch. and Suid. s.v. ἀσηκόρος.
to be careless, Zos.Alch. p.133B.
to be exhausted, weary, LXX Ps. 60(61).2, etc.
proof against enchantment, Od. 10.329 (dub. vers.), Pl. Phdr. 259b; μανίας ἄνθος S. Tr. 999 (lyr.); of the Dioscuri, Theoc. 22.169; ἀ. τὸ ἀπαθές Porph. ap. Eus. PE 5.10.
spotless, ἔσοπτρον, ἐσθής, πέδιλα, LXX Wi. 7.26, Ph. 1.156, Porph. Abst. 2.46: metaph., βίος, ἀρετή, LXX Wi. 4.9, Ph. 2.235; σωτηρία Steph. in Hp. 2.238D.
cure, relief, ὀδυνάων Il. 15.394 codd., Max. 142.

definition: ἀκήν (cf. ἀκή B), acc. form as Adv.,

children.definition: softly, silently, Hom. mostly in phrase ἀκὴν ἐγένοντο σιωπῇ Il. 3.95, al.; also οἱ δʼ ἄλλο ἀκὴν ἴσαν 4.429.
not in a garden, wild, γογγυλίδες Posidon. 29, cf. Gal. 12.509.
purity, Hsch. (ἀκηρεσία in Ms.).

definition: ἀκηράσιος, ον, Ep. form of ἀκήρατος,

children.definition: untouched, ἀ. λειμῶνες meadows not yet grazed or mown, h.Merc. 72; γυίων ἄνθος ἀ. pure, fresh, AP 12.93 ( Rhian.); σκῆπτρα ἀ. inviolate, Epigr.Gr. 907 ( Sinope).

children.label: II
children.definition: κεράννυμι) unmixed, οἶνος Od. 9.205.

undefiled, pure, ὕδωρ Il. 24.303; inviolate, χεῦμα, ὄμβρος, S. OC 471, 690 (lyr.); χρυσός pure gold, Archil. Supp. 4, Alcm. 23.54, Hdt. 7.10.αʹ, Simon. 64, cf. Pl. R. 503a, Plt. 303e; φλόξ Secund. Sent. 5; untouched, unhurt, οἶκος καὶ κλῆρος, κτήματα, Il. 15.498, Od. 17.532; ἀπαρτίη Hippon. 26; σκάφος A. Ag. 661; ἁνίαι strong reins, Pi. P. 5.32; πλόκοι unshorn locks, E. Ion 1266; λειμών unmown meadow, Id. Hipp. 73; ἀ. ἐμπόριον virgin market, Hdt. 4.152; ἀ. φιλία X. Hier. 3.4; ἐπιστήμη, ἤθη, Pl. Phdr. 247d, Lg. 735c; ἀ. φάρμακα spells that have all their power, A.R. 4.157.

undefiled, a virgin, E. Tr. 675, Pl. Lg. 840d; ἀ. λέχος E. Or. 575: c. dat., ἀκήρατος ἄλγεσι, τύχαις untouched by woes, etc., Hipp. 1113, HF 1314: c. gen., ἀ. κακῶν without taint of ill, Hipp. 949; ἀ. ὠδίνων free from throes of child-birth, A.R. 1.974, etc.: poet. Sup. ἀκηρότατος AP 12.249 ( Strat.).

children.label: II
children.definition: κεράννυμι) unmixed, ποτόν A. Pers. 614.
unharmed by the Κῆρες; generally, unharmed, Od. 12.98, 23.328, h.Merc. 530, Nic. Th. 190, Call. Ap. 41, A.R. 3.466; ψυχαὶ ἀκήριοι, = ἀθάνατοι, free from power of the Fates, Ps.-Phoc. 99.

children.label: II
children.definition: having no κῆρ, i.e. with no fortune attached to them, ἡμέραι Hes. Op. 823.

children.label: III
children.definition: harmless, πάμπαν δʼ ἄμωμος οὔτις οὐδʼ ἀ. Semon. 4, cf. Nic. Th. 771.
without heart, i.e.,

children.label: I
children.definition: lifeless, Hom. (not in Od.), ἀκήριον αἶψα τίθησι Il. 11.392. cf. 21.466.

children.label: II
children.definition: heartless, spiritless, σέ που δέος ἴσχει ἀκήριον ib. 5.812, cf. 13.224; ἥμενοι αὖθι ἕκαστοι ἀκήριοι 7.100; ἀκήριον ἠύτʼ ὄνειρον A.R. 2.197.
a plaster, Gal. 13.759.
without flag of truce, ἐπιμείγνυσθαι Th. 2.1; πολεμεῖν D.C. 50.7.

unannounced, unproclaimed, ἀ. πόλεμος sudden war, Hdt. 5.81; also a war in which no herald was admitted, truceless, X. An. 3.3.5, Pl. Lg. 626a, Aeschin. 2.33; ἦν γὰρ ἄσπονδος καὶ ἀ. ὑμῖν πρὸς τοὺς θεατὰς πόλεμος D. 18.262; ἀ. ἔχθρα Plu. Per. 30.

data.quote: ἦν γὰρ ἄσπονδος καὶ ἀ. ὑμῖν πρὸς τοὺς θεατὰς πόλεμος

children.definition: without flag of truce, τὸ ἀ. τῆς ὁδοῦ App. Mith. 104. Adv. -τως, ἐφοίτων Th. 1.146; cf. foreg.

children.label: II
children.definition: not proclaimed victor by heralds, inglorious, E. Heracl. 89, Aeschin. 3.230.

children.label: III
children.definition: with no tidings, not heard of, S. Tr. 45, Nonn. D. 9.249.
unheralded, ἔρωτες ib. 48.653.
unwaxed, Luc. Icar. 3, Polyaen. 2.20.

definition: ἀκῆσκος τάλαρος, Hsch. ἀκητόν· κράτιστον, Id.

children.definition: Hsch. (pl.), cf. EM 48.2.
unadulterated, genuine, Pl. Lg. 916d, Arist. Ath. 51.1; χρυσός Hierocl. in CA Praef. p.417 M.
guileless, honest, Hdt. 9.7.αʹ Adv. -λως Isoc. 1.7.
small barb, BCH 29.572.

definition: ἀκιδνός [ᾰ], ή, όν, Ep. and Ion.,

children.definition: weak, feeble, Hom. only in Od., always in Comp., εἶδος ἀκιδνότερος 8.169, cf. 5.217, 18.130, cf. Nic. Th. 224; later in Posit., δμωαί Man. 2.178: Sup. -ότατον, βέλεμνον Nonn. D. 7.270; insipid, ἔδεσμα Archestr. Fr. 38 B. (s. v.l., καὶ κεδνόν Meineke, Brandt).— Ep. word, also in Hp., ἰατρός Praec. 8: δύναμις Nat.Puer. 30.
barb-like, of quadrilateral with re-entrant angle, Procl. in Euc. p.165 F.
furnish with barb or point, in Pass., βέλη ἠκιδωμένα IG 2.807.

definition: ἀκιδρός ἀσθενής, Cyr. ἀκιδρωπάζω· ἀμβλυωπῶ, Hsch.

children.definition: pointed, Thphr. HP 4.12.2

definition: ἀκιδωτός, ή, όν, = foreg., Paul.Aeg. 6.88, Poll. 1.97, 10.133, Hsch. ἀκῐδ-ωτός, ὁ, = παρωνυχία, Ps.- Dsc. 4.54: ἀκιδωτόν, τό,

children.definition: Id. 2.175; = ποτίρριον, Dsc. 3.15.
without the harp, A. Supp. 681 (lyr.).
powerless, feeble, Od. 9.515, 21.131, Theoc. Ep. 11.

children.label: II
children.definition: weakening, νοῦσος Orph. L. 22.— Ep. word, also in A. Pr. 548 (lyr.), and Ion. Prose, cf. Hp. Morb. 4.43 (in sense 1).
Lyr.Adesp. 30 B (= Call. Fr.anon. 68):—also ἀκιναγμός, ὁ, Hsch.

short straight sword, Hdt. (v. infr.), cf. X. An. 1.2.27 (also acc. -άκεα Hdt. 3.118; pl. -άκεας v.l. ib. 128); ἀ. ἐπίχρυσος, a Persian sword kept in the Parthenon, IG 1.170.17, cf. 2.646.11; νὴ τὸν ἀκινάκην, a Scythian oath, Luc. Tox. 38, cf. JTr. 42. [ ăcīnăces in Hor. Od. 1.27.5.]
without danger, Suid.

free from danger, σιγᾶς ἀ. γέρας Simon. 66; βίος Id. 36, cf. E. IA 17, Th. 1.124; πυρετοί Hp. Aph. 7.63; ἀρεταὶ ἀ. virtues that court no danger, i.e. cheap, easy virtues, Pi. O. 6.9, cf. Th. 3.40; ἀ. εἶναί τινι τὸν ἀγῶνα Hyp. Lyc. 8: c. gen., guaranteed against risk, ἀ. παντὸς κινδύνου IG 12(7).67 ( Amorgos), PTeb. 105.18 (ii B. C.).

children.label: II

Ti. 40b; τὸ πρῶτον κινοῦν ἀκίνητον αὐτό Arist. Metaph. 1012b31; ὕλη ἀ. Stoic. ap. Plu. Stoic.rep. 2.1054a; ἄστρα ἀ. fixed stars, Poll. 4.156.

Tim. 3; κάλλει ἀκμαία Epigr.Gr. 127; τὸ ἀκμαιότατον D.H. 5.22; ἀκμαίων λέσχη at Chalcis, Plu. Aet.Gr. 2.298d:— ἀ. πρὸς ἔρωτα AP 7.221, cf. Luc. DDeor. 13[8].2, Ael. NA 15.10. An. 4.7.1, etc.

Ant. 976; ἀμφιδέξιοι ἀ. both hands, Id. OT 1243; ποδοῖν ἀ. feet, ib. 1034; ἔμπυροι ἀκμαί pointed flames, E. Ph. 1255, cf. πυρὸς ἀκμαί Epicr. 6 codd.

children.definition: highest or culminating point of anything, flower, prime, zenith, esp. of manʼs age, ἀκμὴ ἥβης S. OT 741; ἐν τῇδε τοῦ κάλλους ἀκμῇ Cratin. 195; σώματός τε καὶ φρονήσεως Pl. R. 461a; μέτριος χρόνος ἀκμῆς 460e; ὀξυτάτη δρόμου ἀ. ibid.; ἀ. βίου X. Cyr. 7.2.20, etc.; ἐν ταύταις ταῖς ἀ. Isoc. 7.37; ἐν ἀκμῇ εἶναι, of corn, to be ripe, Th. 4.2; ἀκμὴν ἔχειν τῆς ἄνθης Pl. Phdr. 230b; τοσοῦτον τῆς ἀ. ὑστερῶν Isoc. Ep. 6.4; τῆς ἀ. λήγειν begin to decline, Pl. Smp. 219a:—in various relations, ἀ. ἦρος spring- prime, Pi. P. 4.64; ἀ. θέρους mid-summer, X. HG 5.3.19; βραχεῖα ἀ. πληρώματος Th. 7.14; ἀ. τοῦ ναυτικοῦ flower of their navy, Id. 8.46; ἀ. τῆς δόξης Id. 2.42; ἡ ἀ. τῆς Σπάρτης, τῶν νέων Demad. 12; ἀ. νούσου crisis of disease, Hp. Acut. 38:—generally, strength, vigour, ἐν χερὸς ἀκμᾷ Pi. O. 2.63, cf. A. Pers. 1060; ἀ. ποδῶν swiftness, Pi. I. 8(7).41, cf. A. Eu. 370; φρενῶν Pi. N. 3.39; συμπεσεῖν ἀκμᾷ βαρύς cj. Id. I. 4(3).51: periphr. like βία, ἀκμὴ Θησειδᾶν S. OC 1066.

thing heard, tidings, μετὰ πατρὸς ἀκουὴν ἱκέσθαι, βῆναι, Od. 2.308, 4.701; κατὰ τὴν Σόλωνος ἀκοήν according to Solonʼs story, Pl. Ti. 21a; report, Pi. Phd. 61d; τὰς ἀ. τῶν προγεγενημένων traditions, Th. 1.20; ἀκοαὶ . . λόγων Id. 1.73; ἀκοὴν μαρτυρεῖν, προσάγειν, give, bring hearsay evidence, D. 57.4; βαρὺν . . ἀκοῆς ψόφον AP 6.220 ( Diosc.); ἐκ γὰρ ἀκουῆς οἰκτίρω σε ib. 7.220 ( Agath.).

X. Eq.Mag. 3.6, Str. 11.5.1, Arr. An. 1.2.6; as a contest, OGI 339 ( Sestos); emission of liquids, [ Gal.]19.456, Sch. Il. 17.297.
shooting stars, Ptol. Tetr. 102.

children.label: II
children.definition: Adj., darting, hurtling, τρίαινα Opp. H. 5.535: metaph., μαζοὶ ἀ. ἐρώτων Nonn. D. 7.264:—also in pass. sense, θύρσος, λᾶας, 24.134, 30.230; ἀκοντιστῆρες μόλυβοι prob. bullets, Keil-Premerstein Dritter Bericht p. 89.
engine for hurling projectiles, τὰ τῶν μεγάλων λίθων ἀ. Agath. 3.5.
darter, javelin-man, Il. 16.328, Od. 18.262, Hdt. 8.90, A. Pers. 52, Th. 3.97, Theoc. 17.55, etc.
skilled in throwing the dart, X. Cyr. 7.5.63: Sup., ib. 6.2.4; -κά, τά, art of throwing the dart, Pl. Thg. 126b; -κή, ἡ, Ael. Tact. Praef., Arr. Tact.Praef. Adv. -κῶς Poll. 3.151.
game of the dart, ἀκοντιστὺν ἐσδύσεαι Il. 23.622.
dart-throwing, A.R. 2.1000: as Subst. in pl., Agath. 3.20.
receiving ( i.e. hit by) the dart, Simon. 106.
bearing darts, of persons or things, Nonn. D. 20.148, al.

definition: ἀκόντως, Adv. of ἄκων (B), v. ἀέκων.

children.definition: Pl.Com. 226.
Adv. of ἄκοπος, f.l. for ἀκονιτί, Lib. Decl. 29.6.
freedom from fatigue, Cic. Fam. 16.18.1.
not wearying, ὁδός Arist. Mu. 391a12 (v.l. -ατος).

children.label: II
children.definition: untiring, unwearied, φῶς ἡλίου Herm. ap. Stob. 1.49.44. Adv. -άστως Sch. S. Aj. 852.

= foreg., πρόνοια Stoic. 1.125, cf. IG 2.630b, Vett.Val. 263.17, PMag.Par. 1.1127; ἀ. πίστεις proofs which a writer never tires of repeating, Phld. Mus. p.40 K. Adv. -τως, ἀπολαύειν Id. Piet. 15, LXX Wi. 16.20.
unwearied, Pl. Lg. 789d. Adv. -πως, διαπονεῖν Hp. Vict. 3.70: Comp., ἡγούμενος -ωτέρως ἔσεσθαι τοῖς στρατιώταις prob. in Hell.Oxy. 17.2.
free from trouble, Amips. 28.
unbruised, of fruit, etc., PHib. 49.9 ( Sup., iii B. C.).

children.label: II
children.definition: Act., not wearying, ὄχησις Pl. Ti. 89a; of a horse, easy, X. Eq. 1.6 ( Comp.); τοῖς τετράποσιν ἄκοπον τὸ ἑστάναι Arist. PA 689b17.

removing weariness, refreshing, Hp. Aph. 2.48, Acut. 66, Pl. Phdr. 227a, Agathin. ap. Orib. 10.7.21 ( Comp.):— ἄκοπον (sc. φάρμακον), τό, application (of various kinds) for relief of pain, etc., Dsc. 1.1, Gal. 13.1005, Luc. Alex. 22, etc., cf. Antyll. ap. Orib. 10.29; in Asclep. ap. Gal. 13.343 also ἄκοπος, ἡ.
Dsc. 3.150, Sch. Nic. Th. 71.

children.label: III
children.definition: not worm-eaten, Arist. Pr. 909a19. Adv. -πως, ἔχειν Thphr. CP 4.16.2.
not broken or ground, whole, πέπερι Alex.Aphr. Pr. 1.67; not moth-eaten, ἱμάτια Thphr. HP 4.4.2.
uncut, χόρτος PFlor. 232.11 (iii A. D.).
not manured, Thphr. CP 4.12.3.
with little excrement in the bowels, Hp. Acut. 62.

children.label: II
children.definition: = foreg., Thphr. HP 8.6.4.
producing little excrement, of food, Hp. Acut. 57 ( Comp.).

definition: ἀκοράζεσθαι ἀκροᾶσθαι, Hsch. (i.e. ἀκοϝάζεσθαι). ἀκοραῖος· βλαβερός, ἀνωφελής, Id.

children.definition: insatiate, αὐάτα Lyr.Adesp. 123, Trag. in lyr. passages, A. Ag. 1002, E. Heracl. 927: c. gen., αἰχμᾶς ἀ. A. Pers. 998, cf. Eus.Mynd. 1. Adv. -τως, ὀπυίεσθαι AP 10.56 ( Pall.), cf. Eun. VS p.456B.; ἀ. ὕδατος ἔχειν Gp. 15.9.2, cf. Them. Or. 24.304d.
unceasing, οἰζύς A. Ag. 756; οἰμωγά S. El. 123; νείκη E. Med. 638: Sup., γόοις A. Pers. 545.

children.label: II
children.definition: Act., not causing surfeit, Id. Ag. 1331; φιλία X. Smp. 8.15 ( Comp.).

definition: ἀκόρετος, ον, used in Trag. (metri gr.) for ἀκόρεστος, A. Ag. 1117, 1143, S. El. 122.

children.definition: Them. Or. 7.90d, cf. Hsch. (cod. ἀγκ-): Sup. -έστατος, of a person, S. OC 120 (lyr.).
insatiate, unsated, c. gen., πολέμου, μάχης, ἀπειλάων, Il. 12.335, 20.2, 14.479 (not in Od.), cf. Hes. Sc. 346; προκάδων h.Ven. 71.

children.label: II
children.definition: κόρις) undisturbed by bugs, Ar. Nu. 44 (wrongly expl. by Sch. and Phot. p.63 R. as unswept).
